text: 12oz bottle to tulip. Pours black, solid beige head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, molasses, coffee, dark fruit, oak, bourbon, dark candi syrup. Taste of same. Excellent roastiness. Great complex flavor, while quite quaffable.
Sort of has a musty sweet smell, its hard to describe. Strong dark roast coffee bean flavor, medium bitterness, bit more carb than most dark beers. Pretty damn good overall, quite unique.

Can from Total Wines, Sterling VA. Dark brown in colour, with a decent, off-white, head. A pleasant black lager, with rich chocolate and toasty malts, some brown sugar and plenty of leafy hops, before a lingering, bitter, finish. Easy drinking for the ABV and enjoyable.

Some roast and light caramel. Black pour with good head. Light nut. Crisp and caramel finish. Bottle.
Dark brown pour. Fairly complex flavor of dark roast, nuts, a little dry. Some fruit in the nose too. Good but not great.

2015 BJCP Category: 8B Schwarzbier
AROMA: Fairly generic lager scent; no dark malt or sweetness. Slightly musty, otherwise neutral. 6/12APPEARANCE: Deep ruby red to black proper. Pours a dark reddish brown color. Aromas of roasted malts, bits of chocolate and coffee. Flavor has a nice bitter roast taste and a touch of hops on the finish.

On tap at the Harvest Lounge in the Sheraton Madison Hotel. (WI.) Possessed a clear but deep black/brown hue, with a presentably creamy, tan, and tight bubbled layer of head foam, and sheet-like cling to the lacing. The nose was sweet & malty, with notes of caramel, light coffee, toffee, and slight dark fruit. Medium bodied, with decent liveliness to the carbonation, a nicely creamy texture added to the mouthfeel. The taste included a roasted & earthy bitterness, with dryness, and slight woodiness to the finish. A respectable Dark Lager.
On tap at the brewery. Aroma is faint roasted malt. Flavor is roasted water. Thin and lacking depth. Dont get why people think this is good. Not a drainpour but not much more.

Deep dark reddish brown beer with a medium foamy tan head. Rich nose of cafe au lait, milk chocolate, and brown sugar. Flavor is even richer with the coffee flavors more on the bitter side and some black strap molasses coming through as well. With a high carbonation, this is more easy drinking than others with flavors as bold. Excellent beer.

Black with ruby highlights, solid one-finger head and moderate lace. Roasted coffee aroma with a touch of smoke and chocolate. Bittersweet chocolate powder, dark fruit, and smoke on the palate. Medium body, generous carbonation, very dry finish.
Roasted malt taste mild chocolate and coffee followed by a lingering almost smoke taste. Got better the warmer it got. A little bit to much co2. Good

Beer of month club. Pours a dark brown with slight reddish tint. Not much of a nose. Taste is some cocoa, roasted malts - nice flavor, but much, much lighter than a stout. Really good schwarzbier.

I found this beer to be a little smokey for my liking. Well balance of chocolate and roasted flavor.

on tap at Craftys Taproom in Northeast Phila - aroma is very sweet. Flavor not as sweet. Nice dark reddish color. Slight chocolate flavor.

appearance: deep dark brown, glowing clear ruby when backlit; creamy light tan head that starts at a fingers worth then shrinks to a thin cap; tons of persistent lace cling; looks just like it should. aroma: 	primarily roasty, dry, bittersweet dark chocolate; a bit of chicory, leather, earth, and grass, maybe a whisper of spearmint.  taste: 	roasty coffee and dark chocolate, light molasses, fresh grass, a hint of pepper or smoke. finish: is there a hint of metal in the finish? Maybe, but there seems to be a bit of earthy, mellow hops added to the grassy notes, plus lingering general roasty malts; palate is dry like talc, a bit of smoke too. notes: The two best American schwarzbiers Ive had are from Uinta and Devils Backbone. This isnt far off. Its not quite as good as either, but its still very, very good. To me, just a tad too dry and theres that barest hint of metal on the very back end that I cant seem to shake.

Comes out of tap warm coffee brown with a fine-bubbled and persistent tan head that leaves generous lacing. Aroma presents notes of roast malt and coffee, not strong but enough to make you go Pavlovs Dog. Bold flavor sends roast malt, molasses and mocha tones rolling across the palate; these leave a smoky note in their wake. Firm body, good fizz, and a smoky malt finish round out a great schwarzbier.

Its not often you get to have an American-made Schwarzbier. Its even less often you get to have one thats so good. Black Bavarian looks lovely in any Lager-appropriate glass you pour it into. This bittersweet brew is quite rich for its 6% ABV and approachable despite its dark color. Easy to see why this Sprecher brew continues to be a favorite.

Appearance: Black body with a gorgeous creamy light tan head. It leaves some lacing on the glass.

Aroma: Earthy and but predominantly spicy noble hop scent. I pick up a hint of caramel in the background as well. The scent of this beer isnt that strong, so I really have to get my nose close to it to draw out the aromas.

Taste: Light roasted flavor, a bit of charcoal but only a light bitterness at the back of the tongue. The bitterness does linger though. Some of the hops come through as a bit spicy and it does a good job of increasing the richness of the beer.

Palate: The beer has a fairly strong presence on the palate without being heavy. Its like eating a piece of steak with a well-crusted exterior. It finishes medium-dry leaving just a touch of softness after a sip. It does have a bit more of a sweeter mouthfeel than I would want.

Overall: I think this is a good beer. It has a good balance of roasted flavor and hop spice to make it well worth drinking. It is a very clean beer, having only flavors that I would expect.

16 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark ruby color. It only shows hints of opacity when put against a moderately strong light. The head is a three finger mocha shade that doesnt retain particularly well, as expected. Having said that, I love the soft creaminess of the texture, with just a hint of rockiness to suggest its well hopped. Lacing left on the glass is quite plentiful, also.

S: I get some dark fruit esters, roasted malts, cream, chocolate, caramel, noble hops, and brown sugar on the aroma. Not terribly groundbreaking on its own, but quite impressive given the style. I could certainly compare it to a good porter/stout aromatically.

T: An initial wave of dry chocolate soon gives way to a combination of roasted malts and grassy hops on the back end. While its simplistic and straightforward, its also enjoyably balanced and easy to drink.

M: Its crisp and dry like a good lager should be. On the other end of the spectrum, it actually does a good job of feeling somewhat substantial. At times, the general feel is more reminiscent of a porter than a dinky-ass schwarzbier.

O: I wasnt sure what to expect from this one - its a schwarzbier, yet one of the top examples of the style according to BA. Luckily, Im finding this one pretty damn good. Probably the best schwarz Ive had yet, in fact.

Taste of chocolate, caramel, toast, toffee, molasses, raisin, roasted malt, nuttiness, light coffee, biscuit, earthiness, and herbal spiciness.  Light herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of chocolate, toffee, molasses, roasted malt, toast, raisin, nuttiness, and herbal on the finish for a good bit.  Nice balance and complexity of flavors; nicely robust with zero cloying after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy and lightly slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a very nice schwarzbier!  Nicely robust with good balance and complexity of flavors; very smooth to drink.  Really enjoyed this one.

16 oz bottle pours  black with ruby at the edge.  The tan head is tiny and disappears quickly.  Aroma has roasted/burned malts and chocolate and a bit of smoke in the finish. Ill gladly try this again.
Very very heavy. Uncomfortable to drink. Tastes like ash and booze. What kind of monster could take on an entire pint of this stuff alone?

New Beer Distributors, NY 16 ounce ($2.75): Pours a black color with a small brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malts. Taste is mostly like chocolate and stuff. Not the best black lager I have ever had though.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown color with ruby highlights and a one inch tan bubbly head that fell to a ring and laced the glass.  Aroma is roasty malts, dark fruits and molasses with a touch of chocolate and light mustyness. 12 oz. bottle. From the Mint, Bethlehem, PA. Nearly black in colorwith ruby hues. Lots of malt and coffee up front. the lager yeast is noticeable with a delightful chocolate and roasted character. I have drunk this beer many times and never wrote a review, so now its time to do so. I poured this beer out of a 16 oz bottle into a glass. Now this is a tasty brew.  black pour,  tan foam, aroma of caramel, chocolate, coffee, toast.  Smooth brew, light sweetness, creamy, average carbonation, good clean finish.  Thank you again cheap, Ill have a few for you!

16 oz bottle bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and toffee.  Taste of caramel malts.

Black pour with a head that faded very quickly.  Heavy milk chocolate aroma.  Mouth is thin and the taste is a little plain.  Some roast, some chocolate and a little cheese.  Overall not bad.

16 oz. bottle. Pours a medium, well retained, beige head, over a clear dark brown (SRM 30) body......nose is chocolate, cocoa, lighter coffee, hints of toffee/caramel.....taste is chocolate, coffee, light coffee, touches of toffee/caramel ending with mild hop bitterness....mouth feel moderately thick, carbonation makes a lovely creamy sensation. Dark pour with creamy palate feel. Smooth malty taste with a slight tang of chocolate

On tap at Sprecher Restaurant in Middleton, pours black with a thin tan head, the aroma has a ton of chocolate and malt and the flavor is much of the same.  Nice caramel and malty front end with a finish of chocolate, one of the best options they had on tap here today.
Bottle. Smoky malt, prune, sweet chocolate aroma. Black brown with a small tan head. Smoky chocolate malt, sweet molasses, and little light coffee flavor. Medium body, light carbonation.

Yummy!  Pours a dark BLACK!  Nice tan head that laces well.  Malty aroma with some coffee and chocolate.  taste is roasted malty goodness, chocolate and coffee.  Mouth feel is just right, not too thin, but just thick enough.  Aftertaste is coffee like.  This is one good beer!

16oz bottle from Three Cellars. Pours a very dark cola colored black with a chocolate milk head. Nice spotty lacing. Aroma has a smoky component with caramel, coffee and molasses. Finish has some bitterness and some sweetness, and lasts for a while. Alcohol not too present. A nice brew to drink all day.

On draft at Sprechers Lake Geneva. Pours a jet black color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, roasty. Medium on the palate with creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, bready, roasty, coffee, smokey, with a light smokey finish. Very tasty.

Smokey aroma.  Taste is all over the place. Nutty, caramel, coffee. Maybe even chewing tobacco.  Sharp dryness. Just a great beer.

A dark chocolate with a nutty aroma and a hint of smoke to it.  After tasting it initially I wasnt too interested in it.  But after a moment of sipping it grew on me and its pretty decent on the taste and palate.

Light to medium body with lower than average carbonation and a lingering burnt finish.  I wish the flavor was as good as the smell.  Take a pass on this one.

On tap at Frisco's Grille & Taproom in Columbia, MD. 

Opaque, near black, brown with tiny brown head and fair lacing.

text: Pours really dark reddish black. Nice head and nose of heavy malts, chocolate, coffee, and sweetness. Super creamy with full flavors of bitter coffee, and chocolate. There are some roasted nuts on the finish. Super good!

Poured black with a small silky tan head.  Aroma is very roasted with lots of malts and some nuts.  Taste is quite full and very roasted.  Quite nutty as well with a touch of dark fruits.  Finish is smooth and a little creamy with more roasted nuts.  Overall quite good!

Originally reviewed: 8/6/09. Pours a thick dark black with a big frothy tan head on top. Minimal retention leaves some lacing, but little of it. Smells of faint chocolate, fresh dark breads, hints of coffee, and slight minerals.

Dark with a tan head. Roasty malt aroma. Smooth and toasty with a malty base that is just a bit sweet, nutty, and has a touch of toffee. Very nice and crisp finish. Not too heavy, very drinkable.
Poured from a bottle. Intensely dark, rich aroma, nice hoppy bite. Seems like Guiness with flavor. Great lager.

I get coffee malt carmel and a little toffee from this one but then as it finishes there is a slight coconut. Dark color with malt and honey on the nose. Not too bad at all.

Murky, mostly dark appearance with a small, fast fading, beige head and little lacing.  Aroma of tobacco, coffee and roasted malts. love the layers of flavors that are rolling through this brew! smooth... warming... smooth! yum!!
Pours nearly black with virtually no head. Big coffee and brown bread aroma. Taste is coffee, caramel and bittersweet chocolate. A mighty fine beer.

12 oz bottle. Dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma of dark wheat bread, coffee with a bit of dry chocolate and roasted malt. Flavor is very smooth and malty without being overly sweet, very light hop bitterness for balance. Medium body with average carbonation and a dry, roasty finish. This is an outstanding beer, lots of flavor and very drinkable.

bottle pour into a glass. comes out appearing black (deep brown) with a little head. aroma of malt, caramel and coffee. malty flavor and thin. not what youd expect from the looks of the pour. enjoyable either way!

Review from notes at World of Beer - Fort Myers on 10/30/11. 

Poured on draft into a shaker pint glass. 

Appearance: Pours a very dark brown with caramel highlights and a 1-2 finger creamy tan head. Nice lacing.

Smell: Sweet malt, lactose, chocolate and caramel. Smells delicious.

Taste: Chocolate with german malt and a touch of hops. Roasted malt and chocolate aftertaste. 

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. Goes down smooth.

Overall: Good beer overall. Unfortunately it didnt quite live up to the aroma, but it is definitely worth a try.

Bottle from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. Pours very dark ruddy brown with a slight creamy tan head. Aromas of chocolate and dark caramel. Near full bodied. Flavor is dark charred toffee with some chocolate and a hint of coffee. Drinks nicely.

From on tap at the MOTR pub/cafe in the Over-The-Rhine district in Cincinnati, Ohio - This is a fine, near perfect textbook example of a great schwarzbier, with complexity and sweetness! I like this beer!

On tap at Barcade, Brooklyn, New York, NY. A black coloured pour with a small beige head on top. Malty, caramel aroma. Tastes malty, caramel, coffee, chocolate. Smooth and surprisingly easy to drink. Good stuff.

From my Asheville, NC, beer log: On tap, Coffee black, has some stout/porter characteristics, but has a little bit of a  watery mouthfeel. Some dark roasted malts and chocolate, perhaps some plums deep down in the taste. Overall very nice and smooth, and not as heavy as expected.

Twist-off bottle into Sam Adams Boston Lager glass. Dark brown-black; pretty nice brown head that sticks for a couple of minutes. Aroma of chocolate and coffee, some doppelbock maltiness, and lager lurking underneath. Mouthfeel more like an ale--a bit syrupy; lacks the lager crispness. Earth emerges in the finish. Nice beer, but stylistically I prefer crisper schwarzbiers.
me thinks i got an oxidized bottle of this, because it had a chemcial-y aroma and flavor throughout.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black with small dark brown highlights.  Pretty good lacing, medium body, and thick smooth texture.  Taste is roasted malt, coffee, and light hops in the finish.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Imperial Pint/Pilsner hybrid.

Appearance: Near black reddish-brown with thin brown head.

Aroma: Bittersweet chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, molasses, and spicy,metallic noble hops.

Taste: Molasses and chocolate malt upfront with light roasted notes and coffee. Very light noble hops on the finish.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, creamy and smooth body, fairly full for a lager.

Overall: Excellent Schwarzbier that may almost have too much flavor to be as easy drinking as some within the style.
On tap at the Sheraton in Madison, WI.  Notes only.  Burnt roasted malt aroma.   Taste has a nice roasted/burnt bitterness.   Chocolate and coffee notes come through in the end.
Draft at Thirsty Monk.  Nice black pour, delicious malty chocolate and coffee flavors.  Good solid schwarzbier.  I look forward to trying some of their other offerings.
I didnt really dig this. A very pretty black beer. Smell is sour. Flavor is hints of roast malt and an overpowering sourness and overly spritzy. Eh.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.
Bottle. Deep, dark color. Aroma, is sweet, nutty, caramel . Taste is not quite as sweet, more bitter, burnt toast.

Bottle, medium creamy deep beige head, opaque brown colour, aroma of coffee and hay with some floral notes and a hint of porchini mushrooms, flavout of roasted coffee with some dried fruits and charred wood in the back,  long bitter aftertaste. Nice but nothing too exceptional.

Pours black with touches of ruby on the edges and a tan head. Smells malty, chocolate and a touch of bread. Tastes like cocoa, bread and a touch of graininess. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and decent mouth-carbonation, Sprecher Black Bavarian finishes smooth with some slight bitterness.

Pour from a 16 oz (screw off top) bottle. Inky dark brew iwth thin head that quickly dissapates, but leaves a persistent frothy film. Aroma of burnt malts, toastedmalts, a bit of roasted coffee. taste is dominated by the malts - nice blend of roasted malts but with a little sweet still in there. Dry finish with a little bitter at the end. Palate is light but satisfying, with a little active carbonation. Overall very nice and well done.

Date: July 21, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Miller Brew House, Milwaukee, WI Airport Appearance: Opaque black and minimal tan head that faded quickly. Aroma: Caramel and chocolate. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, slightly carbonated but very smooth, and slight chocolate and bitter finish. Other: Like drinking a chocolate bar, yummy.

Beer of the month, pours an amazing black with a creamy huge head, aroma of white chocolate, vanilla, toffee and caramel, flavor is smokey with some hash, with lots of coffee, sour cherries, caramel and wood, medium to full bodied
Bottle from Cavie.  Dark pour with red edges and an off-white head.  Aroma is roasted, chocolate, and licorice.  Taste is roasted, dark chocolate, bitter, and almost coffee.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color that edges on black. Some tan head. Roasted malts with some decent coffee aromas. Slight chocolate. Flavor is chocolate and roasted malts. Finishes a bit chocolatey. Not bad.

This one was a hard one to rate. Very complex! Aroma of malt and coffee. Tastes of molases, coffee, malt, and a little liqourice. Its a Suprisingly good beer. Very complex!  Wow this is one of the worst reviews ever, I cant describe this one, but its good!

From bottle. Rich sweet molasses aroma, malty with roasted barley and very light hops. Clean. Dark black-brown, clear, with very thin off-white head. Medium watery body with medium-high carbonation. Starts medium sweet with molasses, chocolate, and roasted barley. Medium hop bitterness and some roasted malt acidity. Carbonic gaseousness and a bit of chocolate. Sweet nutty after with a bit of bitterness.

Pours brown with clear mahogany edges and a large foamy tan head that fades fairly quickly. Aroma of that fresh steeping malts and roasty malts, some floral hop. Taste is nice, pretty mild, nice toasty bready finish, some chocolate as well. Very easy drinking, body is a little on the thinner side

pours black with a very minimal off white head.  aroma is black licorice and chocolate with a hint of fruit.  taste has a hint of hops countering the strong dark malt character.  notes of caramel, licorice and chocolate are present.  body is medium with a juicy sort of character.  finish is dry.
Always good and consistant. Pours a thick coffee like mixture, Hints of cocoa and spice. Nine burps.

Thanks for BeerFMAndy for the bottle. Served in a pilsner glass.

The pour is near black with an initial two-finger tan had that settles down pretty quickly without leaving much lacing behind. Theres just a slight film of light foam on top. Initial whiff brings some light roast and some mild, smooth chocolate.

Flavor is light chocolate and some very mild coffee. Theres some light roast malt there as well in addition to a very light amount of caramel. Mouthfeel is light and airy without all that much carbonation. This finish is moderately dry. Pretty good, but nothing fantastic. Definitely not a mind-altering schwarzbier.

Serving type: bottle

not pitch black, but fairly dark pour. thin head with light lacing. Basement aromas and cigarette nose. Taste is very smokey, roasty, ashy. Coffee and cigarettes after a night of hookers and blow. Picked up a 16oz bottle for $2.25. Good beer for the ABV and the money,  I suppose, but not really my thing.

The beer pours a clear, very dark garnet color with a fairly small, pale tan, pillowy head which is mostly diminishing and leaves minimal lace.  The nose is quite bland; some light coffee, buttered dark toast, dark caramels, and maybe a hint of sour bread yeast.  The flavor is similar but nicer with faint dark chocolate, lots of dry caramels, Belgian chocolate, restrained roast, and buttered dark toast all all with a light moderate acidity and a light bitterness.  The palate is nearly medium, silky and crisp, and lively.  The beer finishes fairly long and drying with burnt toast, bitter from the roast, and still caramelly with a slight note of the sour yeast.  Really had the potential to be a great schwarz, but the off-note of the sour yeast killed it for me.  Not sure why the ratings are incredibly high for the style considering most of the "top raters" do not have it rated nearly as high as the average?  My first from this brewery.

smells dark chocolate, caramel.  Appearance is black/brown lace around edges.  Tastes malt, low hops, not the best of the brews Ive had that day, but definitely very complex.  Burnt toast, sweet, little hops.  Im sure alot of ppl would enjoy this, but I prefer an irish red ale or amber ale with my food.

Bottle. Pours almost black with a hint of red with frothy tan foam. Smells roasty and slightly sweet of liccorice. Tastes clean, wiith dark roasty malts, hints of liccorice and smoke, and feels creamy.

16oz bottle with old school logo

Black but slightly red. This beer smells like goodness. Roasted, malt, a little coffee. It is one of my favorite beers right now. It is super drinkable and it can sit it my mouth before it goes down smooth and awesome! It has a bitter taste, but it is still sweet and rich. It has a burnt caramel aftertaste that leaves my lips smackin. If you havent tried this beer and you like porters, youve got to try this one.

16 oz bottle with twist off cap.

Pours into my mug a nice deep, dark brown with red hues when held to light. The head is frothy and creamy at is rises slightly over the lip. It is light tan and does not recede at all really for a long time.

The smell is of cocoa mostly and some standard lager scents: bread and light hops. It isnt the best smelling example of this style, but for what it is it works.

The flavor is good, with some nice roasty malts. It is heavy on the roasted chocolate flavor. It is a bit heavy for the style which is basically a dark colored beer that should drink like a pilsener. This one is more like a porter.

It is a good try for an american company, but there are a few German examples that I would rather have.

Serving type: bottle

12 oz. Opaque ebony with a creamy little head. Aromas of toasted walnut, espresso, smoke, cream and chocolate. Heavy body is velvety smooth, slightly watery, and well-balanced with a sweet entry and a prickly-dry, acidic finish. Flavors of chocolate espresso, sweet cream, ash, smoke, green herb, and some iron.
Pours a slightly lacing tan head with a dark brown body.  Aroma is roasted, toasted, hint of smoke.  Flavor is much the same.  Nice and rich.

Bottle sampled with JerCraigs. Pours very dark with a slightly reddish hue and a moderate head. Significant lacing. Roasted malt aroma. Taste is chocolate and caramel, very light mouthfeel. Hint of bitter to finish. Lovely balance. Very good.

A nice, dark, malty brew.  Pretty sweet for the style, with some chocolate and molasses notes.  Nice floral scents in the aroma.  It goes down smooth and easy.  This stuff deserves its good reputation.
Pours black with off white head, next to no lacing.  Bread like aroma.  Slightly sweet with smokey burnt malt, finishing with a burnt bitter taste.
UPDATED: JUL 28, 2012 Very big roasted malt flavor thats close to stout levels and yet somehow still sessionable.  The twist-top is deceiving, this is a great beer.

Source: Pint bottle from local retailer

Aroma: Faint overall aroma smells slightly sweet. From the smell alone the use of coffee and bittersweet chocolate is obvious.

Appearance: Surprisingly thin mocha colored head. Beer itself is extremely dark brown/black. No light permeates through when held up to a window. Very little permeates through when held up to a direct light source.

Taste: Initial taste is bittersweet with a rather prominent chocolate note. Roasted coffee taste and caramel come through on the finish.

Palate: Body isnt overly thick, overall quite smooth to drink. The finish lingers on for a while after you finish the beer.

Overall: Quite enjoyable. Admittedly one of my favorite local brews. I like to drink it in the fall and winter; its not the kind of beer I think Id want on a hot summer day. Thats just my opinion, though.

Location: Sampled at the NY Brewfest on Governors Island, 6/19/10


Aroma: The nose is fairly malty: burnt, roasted, and caramel mostly

Appearance: Th pour is dark, brown/black color, a little red, largish frothy head

Flavor: Caramel and roasted malts, somewhat sweet, decent bitterness too, balanced

Palate: It has a decent mouthfeel, relatively long duration, and medium body

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty solid dark beer.  Not anything crazy or super exciting, just solid and drinkable, but that is no knock.  This stuff is decent enough for what it is trying to be.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, fizzy/frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, chocolate, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers), with a note of vanilla.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation.

Tasted side-by-side with Rogues Dirtoir, which was easily better.  This ones not bad, but less roasty and less distinctive...and less Schwarzbier-ish, perhaps more importantly.  More like an American-style porter.

Sampler from the Sprecher  brew pub in Lake Geneva; part of a 3 part sampler....life is good.  Black with thin tan head; coffee nose.  Mild malty taste with hints of mild coffee and cocoa. Mild, smooth palate.  A good match with the short ribs at dinner.  Will do this one again.

Bottle from Sams, Durham. Nice that Sprecher finally decided to start sending their beers to us, and not just their delish sodas. First time I tried this I didnt necessarily have a robust appreciation for schwarzbiers. I now do, and its a treat to reacquaint myself with this boss example of the style. Dark, cola-like pour with a brimful head. Sharp roasted malts in the nose, but also more than just this one dimension - some sweet sugars, dry barley and hops, a trace of fruit. Mouthfeel just a bit on the prickly side. Really nice flavors, with a deep dark center rounded out by hints of citrus, a pleasantly dry (but not papery) finish, and a mellowed roasted quality throughout. Yummy.

Pours jet black with a thin tan colored head.  Looks like a fine Schwarz.  It has a coffeeish nose, notes of chocolate with a pronounced roasted nuttiness and some smoke.  Nice flavors.....licorice, day-old coffee, dark chocolate....roasted malts and grains...with a good, lingering smokey finish.   Medium-thick body, oily, salty but smooth and creamy at the same time.  Solid offering.
Dark and smooth, light carbonation. Slight creamy head. The flavor is rich and satisfying with hints of molasses, chocolate, licorice. Smooth, balanced finish. My favorite Sprecher beer.

Appearance: Received from the bartender a simple black body topped with a slim, light beige head.

Smell: Nose smelling of roasted, grainy malts for a dull coffee-ish tone, touches of chocolate and caramel with a spoonful of sweet homemade plum jelly.

Taste: Blackened barley malt, with a slow but steady accumulating roasted grain quality to it. Sweet influences of chocolate and caramel, more prominent in the beginning. Subtle albeit continuous ripe plum fruitiness. A hint of herbs pulls in a slight, sweetness-tempering bitterness. Late touch of aniseed. Finishes fairly dry with a light, final touch of chocolate.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium-light carbonation.

Drinkability: Its a good schwarzbier tweaked with less than traditional ingredients, though I am not willing to say it is a great one.

Aroma: prominent dried fruit (even though I guess a Schwarzbier supposedly isnt supposed to exhibit this characteristic) and cocoa/coffee, roasty; Appearance: rich dark brown with just a bit of transluscence, looks a lot like Sprechers rootbeer; Taste: very rich and flavorful without being heavy, actually almost thirst quenching in a way, a very good beer to have with dinner, prominent roasty malt flavor, reminds me of smoked gouda cheese somehow, also cocoa more than coffee can be pulled out; Palate: this is one of those rare beers that just has the perfect aftertaste, everything is so balanced, man Im just really loving this one; Overall: living near Wisconsin, Ive taken the Sprecher Brewery tour a couple of times, and I have to say that, for those of you that have had it from a bottle and loved it, youll enjoy it even more straight from the source, take a trip up to WI and find out for yourself, Huzzah!
Bottle. Poured black with a brown head that settled to a ring and left light lace. Roasted malt aroma. The flavor found chocolate and roast. Medium body and roasted malt aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2010 Three cheers for Wisconsin, and Bavaria, two places on this planet that will forever be linked through culture and beverages. This beer is exceptional in every way, just like the people who cteated it, and carry on that tradition today.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown, Mild Off White head; aroma is a nice caramel malt with a hint of chocolate. Medium Bitterness at the offset, flavors are a nice coffee, caramel malt, chocolate, a roasted element, finishes a little bitter here, nice brew. My first "schwarz"
Tan head one finger slowly dissipates, roasted chocolate aroma and nuts, dark mahogany color, soft carbonation, thin feel, roasted burnt coffee flavor with a dark chocolate maltiness.

Pint bottle from Sams in Durham.  Pours dark brown, nearly black, but definitely some light showing through the edges.  Light tan head.  Lovely nose of roasty chocolate malts, some caramel and creamy notes, as well as some nuts.  Mild sweet coffee.  Some lactic notes come through bit a more on the taste.  Quite good, definitely the best Ive had from this brewery.

Tasted 8/17/10. 16oz pint bottle. Filtered, yet pours mildly opaque with a subtle dark amber highlight. Layer of light khaki head. Toasty aromas with a light brownie note. Medium to full bodied with a great malt bill. Toasty and malty. Subtle sweetness in the finish. Good astringency and effervescence. Cloying finish, which is a definite attribute! Great dichotomy between the bitter and sweet palate. Solid and top notch!
bottle, dark brown color with tan ring, aroma is roast and smoke, really good flavor of smoke, bit o honey, dry wood, dark chocolate, coffee, finish is bitter

Poured into pilsner glass. No freshness date on bottle.

Pours a thick brown head. Surprisingly leaves little to no lace. Color is a deep bronze/brown, almost black.

Aroma is full of honey and chocolate, mainly roaty malts. Taste is quite similar, very malty. Dark chocolate and earthy hops are present.

First thing about the aftertaste is that the malts seem to be very burnt. Other than that, the mouthfeel is very creamy and leaves a dry aftertaste.

Overall, a very tasty beer. Pretty easy to drink. I would have to recommend this one.

Serving type: bottle
