UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 Excellent example of Schwarzbier.  I love this stuff. Dark and lovely but still so so drinkable. Serving: Bottle and tap

Bottle.  Pours a pitch black color with a nicely developed tan head.  Dark roasted chocolate malt aromas with a bit of coffee and caramel.  The flavor is quite nice with a mixture of bittersweet chocolate and coffee notes.  A touch of bitterness in the finish.
Black pour with tons of brown/tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Much more on the chocolate side. Flavor is is chocolate with a slight bitterness. A sweeter finish.
Stellar black lager.  The roasted caramel and chocolate malts create a smooth and sweet texture.

500ml bottle. 

Appearance : Black medium head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Caramel, roasted malts, raisins. Quite a lot of caramel. Notes of coffee and hops.

Taste : Roasted malt, coffee biterness. Finish is roasty with notes of coffee and overcooked caramel. Notes of raisins and hops.

Overall : Carbonartion quite soft, very easy-drinking. Nose is nice but not exactly my thing. Taste is pretty good. Nice roastyness. Nice light bitterness on the finish. Im not that much into this beer style but this one is quite good.

A reddish brown lager with a very thin off white head. In aroma, nutty chocolate with light sourish notes. In mouth, a smooth chalky chocolate, powdery, a bit underwhelming. Medium bodied. On tap at Datz, May 24 2010.
on tap-pours a tan head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-roasty/licorice.  Taste is dark malt-roasty/licorice/ashy, some dark fruit, earthy hops.

Tap at the brewery. Jet black pour with slightly creamy off-white head. Aroma is loaded with bitter coffee grounds and has notes of roasted malt and hops. Flavor is slightly over bitter coffee, plenty of roasted malt, caramel, and hops. Bitter and burnt finish. Light body. Not quite what I was expecting in terms of the harshness of the coffee.
Pours black with minimal head and little lively carbonation. Smells of smoke, spice, and chocolate. Tastes of moss, smokey malts, and some chocolate. Really really good beer from sprecher.

Poured from 16 oz bottle.  Ive had a couple of bad Sprecher brews in the past so I was apprehensive about purchasing, but the RateBeer reviews were good so I decided to try it out, and boy Im glad I did.  Aroma is of alcohol, chocolate and malt, its not overpowering but not anything to whiff at either.  Pour is pure black.  Taste is honestly like a low alcohol Dark Lord from Three Floyds...thats what Im tasting anyways.  Its rich in chocolate and coffee and is incredibly smooth.  Will have to try again!

12 oz. bottle as an extra in a trade with fidelis83- thanks again, Jeremiah!  Pours an opaque dark brown with a finger-thick tan head with decent retention and light lace.  Aroma of roasted malts, with chocolate, caramel, toast, and not much else.  The flavor follows suit, with roasted malts leading the way and cola, chocolate, caramel, and some earthy notes.  Medium-bodied, with above average carbonation and a cola-like mouthfeel.  Nice sweet undertones and a distinct German character.  Surprisingly impressive beer; I had known Sprecher before mostly for their root beer.

Pours a dark brown almost black color with slight amber edges when held to a light source and a 1.5 finger tan head that slowly fades into a lasting ring. Sporadic splotches os soapy lacing left behind.

Roasted chocolate malt aroma with some earthy hop bitterness, roasted coffee, toffee, licorice and some smoked malt.

Medium bodied with a lot of roasted chocolate maltiness with hints of deep roasted coffee, caramel, oatmeal and toffee. There is surprisingly a nice btter hop presence that adds a bit of complexity and lingers into a dry finish.

One of the better beers Ive had from Sprecher.

Bottle. Black with a nice ring of foam. Aroma is all about roasted/burnt grainy toast with a hint of smokiness. Taste is quite mellow, a bit of sweetness up front but the roasted grain gives it a nice bitter finale. Palate is quite creamy and great for a lager. I could definately see myself downing a couple of these in a row if they were readily available.

Sprecher Brewing Company, Inc.--Black Bavarian Style Lager--2007 12 oz. Bottle.  5.86% ABV.  32 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Beer of the Month Club Selection June, 2007.  6% ABV on Bottle.  Big lacy espresso head.  Clear mahogany red dark black color.  Rich chocolate mild hop front.  Creamy smooth rich mild sweet chocolate malt mild fruit rich malty lager body.  Mild zesty hop spice cloying espresso smooth end.  Malty Porterish.  Sampled 2/3/2009.

opaque black, thin but lasting dense tan head.

aroma: could smell overripe banana from across the table, sweet chocolate malt, quite mineraly up close.

taste:
T1= mineral/metallic, slight wheat.
T2= slightly hoppy, sweet roasted malt, a bit of charred fruit.
T3= metallic/mineral that fades into charred malt.

Bomber via trade thanks to koopa on BA.  Tried it side-by-side with my homebrewed schwarzbier.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head and decent retention.  Aroma is pretty nice: roast, chocolate, sweet caramel, and slight coffee.  Flavor is similar to the aroma.  Caramel malt, milk chocolate, and roast.  Not much hop character.  Smooth on he palate with medium body.  Pretty good beer, but my homebrewed hoppy clone was better I must say!

Pours dark black with a tan head that disappears quickly.  A slight ring lingered around the edge, but for the most part, a creamy beer with little carbonation.  Aroma is roasted coffee with hints of chocolate, and not as much smokiness as I was expecting.  Its got just the right amount of hops to balance the heavy malts and the chocolate/roasted malt flavors are delightful.  Not as heavy as a porter or stout, this creamy schwarzbier delivers.

Pours deep brown with off white head, aroma is some coffee and a bit of hops.  Taste is nice and smooth with a coffee overtone, chocolate, hops, and a bit of a roasted undertone.  Nice and flavorful yet immensely drinkable.

16oz bottle. Pours thin black with a small tan head. The aroma is comprised of coffee, chocolate, roasty, smoke, a little hoppy grassiness. Tastes slightly sweet with medium to heavy bitterness and it leaves a little sourness on the palate.

Pours jet black with a tan head. Taking a whiff of this beer hits you with caramel malts. Full bodied, very syrupy. It tastes just like it smells, but with some hints of chocolate and a medium bitter finish. Not too shabby.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours black and almost but not quite opaque.  Light tan lacy head.  Good but mild nose.  Most roasted malts with little hints of cocoa.  The flavor is much bolder though still very smooth.  Fairly sweet with a nice bitterness to balance it out.  Very roasty and even a tad smoky.  Surprisingly creamy mouthfeel for a lager, even a black one.  Pretty damn good.
caramel, chocolate, coffee, toast, black, brown, hazy, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, average carbonation,  bitter,

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2012 Smell is a little meaty dark. V ery nice black pour tho not opaque. Burned woode flavors from the beginning, turns interestingly bitter but never over the top. Yes, a real dark beer experience without that nasty bitter high alky experience. Makes me wish I lived closer to wisconsin, eh?  Lively average carbonation. Zoomee zoomee zeemee. A very inexpensive beer that is high in the percentile. Does not show its alky content willingly. Overall a decent example that a cheap beer can provide many of the characteristics that a good beer should.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 25, 2010 Pours black with amber hue, yellow-tan head that flattens out over a few seconds.  Deep roast aroma, light caramel notes.  Refined roasted flavor that does not detract or overwhelm from the overall taste.  Very smooth, creamy.  Light malt bitterness and dryness at the end. Almost a woody-type, cask flavor.  One of the first craft beers I ever tried and still as good today.

Bottle.  Pours an intense black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is rich, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, some molasses.  All those are there in the flavor too, plus some nice hop balance.  Body is medium, palette is very creamy.  Finish is dry and smooth.  A very well made, satisfying beer.  Love it, but this is also one of my favorite styles.

Very well made, and if you like this type of beer, youll love the Black Bavarian, but not for me. I like black lagers that are lighter in flavor and body - easier to drink. This crossed into that sour burnt ashy flavor too much - it was wonderfully creamy, and the choco - coffee flavors were nice.

The pour reveals a black color with brown highlights and a thin light brown head. Solid aroma of molasses, chocolate and roasted malt. Very good flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, molasses and mild fruityness. The body is light while the texture is creamy and the carbonation moderate. From the limited experience I have from this style of beer, this is the mother of all schwarzbiers.
DecemBeer. Sample from a bottle shared by me.  Tan cover, dark brown, red hints.  Aroma is roasty, chocolate.  Taste is roasty, chocolate, caramel.
pours black with beige head and red highlights. Arouma of chocolate, prune coffee. Taste is the same with a nice light-hoppy floral character. Nice springy carbonation. A well balanced beer.

Bottle at an impromptu tasting at lithys. Pours reddish black with small beige head. The aroma is mild chocolate, marshmellow, some roasty notes, chalk, and a hint of smoke. The flavor is somewhat smoky with some chocolate and roasted elements. Fairly simple and straightforward, but tasty.

A: Pours black as the ace of spades (drinking while playing online poker) with a nice thick two finger head made up of the tiniest of bubbles. There is some lacing left behind.

S: Nice malty aroma. Definite notes of chocolate and coffee. There is a floral quality about it as well. Cant pick out the flower, but its in there and the sweetness is very nice.

T: Very good brew, the best I have ever had from Sprecher. Very malty with a wonderful taste of charred malts that brings out a dark roasted coffee taste with chipped milk chocolate. It finishes with a chary bite. Not sure if its hops, or just deeply charred malts. What ever it is I like it.

M: Medium bodied and pretty flat.
Delicious German-style beer aroma. Not much head. Full-bodied taste is a pleasant blend of malts - bread, chocolate, coffee, nuts, roasty. Minimally hoppy. Earthy and woody.

On tap at Local 44 in Phila, PA.  Pours a dark brown-mostly black with an inch of thick brown/gray head.  Smell is of blackberries, chocolate and burnt malt.  Mouthfeel is very thick but not oily at all.  Kind of like a porter but lighter; its one of the beers many highlights.  Taste is of coffee and milk chocolate with lots of fruit such as blackberries, dark cherries and nuts.  I almost didnt order this beer because I havent had too many Schwarzbiers but Im glad I did.  Its very much like a stout but lighter on the palate and with less bitterness.  Its so easy to drink despite the dark color because its fairly medium bodied and very smooth.  This was an awesome beer and I highly recommend it to anybody!

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2010 This beer is honestly an A+.  Everything is just the way you want it to be.  The aroma is sweet chocolate, coffee, caramel malt.  The appearance is rich, dark, and intimidating.  The taste isnt as sweet as the nose though.  It has a nice complex flavor.  The palate on this beer is amazing.  For such a rich and flavorful beer, Black Bavarian is very smooth.  It finishes clean and doesnt have that unnecessary bite some other schwartz beers have.  The palate is creamier on tap than in the bottle.  Overall, it is tough to beat, making it one of my top beers.

The aroma is nicely roasted German lager malt. A little sweet, on the bready end of the scale, but also has a sharp bite.

Appearance is a clear orange-yellow. Nice fluffy head. Color = average, head = good. Not sure where this so-called "black" is.

The flavor is sweetish malt, but with a roasted, toasted bite on the back end. Caramel and corn syrup malt. Hops are negligible.

Feels unexpectedly gritty and sandpapery. Its a decent, heavily malted brew.

Pitch black pour with a thin beige head.  The aroma is wonderfully inviting.  Coffee and cream, chocolate, and caramel.  Smooth and quite drinkable with a punch of carbonation at the end.  The flavor lives up to the aroma.  Sweetness up front with the caramel and chocolate making their presence known.  Theres a great finish of slightly bitter coffee.  A wonderful ber.
There is a reason this beer has won awards for best in style--it really is that good.  It is too bad everything Sprecher produces is not this good.
TAP: black pour, tan head. Aroma of malt and coffee, nice thick mouthfeel with coffee, chocolate, roast - good depth of taste. Awesome beer.

Bottle - Black pour with a little tan head. Smell is smooth chocolatey malt with a bit of lactose. Taste is dark roast and smoke with some nice lactose notes. Its smooth, medium-full bodied, and pretty tasty, but didnt blow my mind like I remembered it doing 10 years ago. I think my tastes have changed a bit since then.
Bottle.22 oz. Pours deep brown with a beige, thick, tan head. Aroma of chocolate, pepper, spice, coffee, oatmeal, and malts. Full, thick body with a powerful finish. Very good.

really thin and watery palate with a miniscule aroma. color is really dark but it still is translucent and has a white head. aside from that it has a fantastic flavor of dark roasted malts and ice water. very refreshing, and worth buying a few bottles of. On Tap at Zekes Roadhouse, Miami Beach.
This beer is full of flavor.  It is not as heavy as it looks, but is somewhat heavy.
Dark pour.  tan head.  Caramel, chocolate, coffee and some cracker hints.  Flavor is very malty, some coffee, cane syrup and some chocolate. Not bad.
Had after a tour of the brewpub.  Coffee up front with a caramel finish - good stuff.

2008 bottle. Pours simply opaque...as black as they come, with quickly fading tan head. Faint aroma is caramel and dark malt with some chocolate cookie hints. Taste is good roasted malt, good coffee black, good hint of molasses, good rich caramel, but some kind of bad funky almost sour note in the background that really distracts throughout. Could just be the Schwarzbier style...not one I can say Im a fan of just yet. Alot of good things going on in this one, just a little disappointing in the finish.

[2338-20090726] 16floz bottle. Sweet cherry wood and mild caramel floral aroma. Very dark red brown body with a quick foamy light brown head. Roasted wood malt flavour has hints of dark chocolate and is initially thin followed with a heavy roast and long finish. Full body. Very roasty, good.
(w/ jerc, manuchampions)

Pours black with a very cream, dense tan head that lingers after its poured. Aroma is slightly sour, lots of peat, caramel with a light chocolate, coffee and smoke note. Flavor starts off sweet with a chocolate kick but quickly moves to a bitter coffee/black patent kick, light dark fruit note toward the end with a very dry finish. Brew has a great mouth feel due to it being super smooth and well carbonated. Overall a fantastic brew and one I that you can drink any time.
On tap at blue palms. Pours with a kahki head over a brown body. Aroma of coffee, caramel and light smokey bacon. Taste is coffee, smoke, a bit bitter. Creamy bubbles.

2009-07-26. Black body with a modest foamy tan head that fades. (3+) Aroma has an unexpected sweet fruit touch. Light caramel and earthy malt touches. Flavour is sweeter than expected, light fruity overtones, sweet malt base that has a light tang in the finish. Smooth medium bodied palate is lightly carbonated. (3+)  Bottle says the expiry date is 0709, so it may have more time beyond the few months in my cellar. I was expecting more of a bitter roasty schwarzbier, and it came off as more porter like. Decent, bit quirky, but pleasant overall. Bottle from HogTownHarry

Shiny black, airy brown layer of foam that lingers briefly. The rich rummy butter and smokey molasses nose of a warm sticky toffee pudding, sweet date notes around the edges. Coal smoke roast, pleasantly high frequency with only a faint caramel and raisin middle note. Toasted rye bread exhale with a little ashy cocoa finish. Distinctive, well-crafted beer.

The aroma is earthy, vegetable, wood, coffee.  The appearance is black (duh!), an inky black, tan head.  The flavor is roasted coffee, chocolate, vegetable/tomato, molasses. The finish is light earthy hops, and roastiness.  Medium smooth mouthfeel.  Decent beverage.

Sprecher Black Bavarian is a solid black lager with a fluffy brown head.  Wooden spice, sweet malt and roast are in the aroma.  Its medium-full bodied and incredibly smooth with a slightly astringent finish.  Big, chewy roasted malt is the flavor here.  Its balanced, bold and simple.  The wooden spice is in the taste too.  Its almost a touch tart.  This is very enjoyable-- a supreme lager!

Pours black with thin brown head. big roasted flavor, slightly nutty and bitter sweet. the palate was creamy but not too heavy. I took my time with this one.  Nice to drink slowly.  Thanks for the trade JB.

16oz Bottle  Trade - JJClark
Aroma: Dark malt with a smokey and earthy aroma. 
Appearance: Dark Brown in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Sweet malt flavor with smoked peat flavors.  
Palate: Dry finish, with a Good Schwarz Mouthfeel.  
Overall: This was a nice beer.

12 ounce bottle from a friend. Pours an opaque black color with a medium creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, bitter coffee and fairly strong hop notes. Medium bodied. Creamy, smooth texture. Very nice.
Excellent winter beer or used in cooking stews and soda breads, etc. Another local company that really knows their stuff!

Bottle pour.The aroma is roasted malt with hints of coffee and chocolate.Dark burgundy color with a great beige head.Tasted like it smelled with roasted malt,chocolate,coffee and hints of caramel and oak.Very smooth beer and the aftertaste didnt stay too long.This one was damn good.Have to find more.

Draught at Creekside in SLO.   Nice and completely random find at this infant brewpub, which is still supplementing its house beers with some carefully chosen guest taps.   The beer is a very dark brown with a thick tan head.   Rich malt, caramel, light chocolate, and toasty aroma, all with a  clean lager profile.   The flavor is solidly malty with light hops.   Plenty of caramel, chocolate, and light roast finishing it up.   Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.   Smooth and tasty.   Solid dark lager, and something I could drink in quantity.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2010 Beer poured a rich black color with a mostly creamy head.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and a hint of molasses.  Flavor a great balance of chocolate and coffee with a kiss of hops in the finish.  Best of the three black lagers Ive had so far (Kostrizer Schwarzbier and Sam Adams Black were the other two).

Bottle.  Played beer pong with this after Ive waited to get my hands on this for over a year... IDIOT! but desperate times call for desperate measures.  Pours blackish.  Tastes of roasted malts, tons of smoked bacon.  Interesting but not what I picture as a schwartzy.

Courtesy of qmeister.  Black porter-like color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and caramel.  Creamy.  Flavor caramel, chocolate, roasted malts, decent lacing.  Porter-like consistency.  Very nice beer!
bottle thanks to GMCC2181.  poured black with a beige head.  aroma was wet grains, dark roasts, and caramel.  flavor was dark roasts, grains, caramel, and chocolate.  light body and high carbonation.

Bottle thanks to GMCC2181. Pours a deep dark brown/black with red hues and tan head. Aroma of obvious chocolate, rich caramel, some coffee. Flavor is is the same, a tad more coffee though....Mouth feel is medium body with medium-high carbonation. Overall, I enjoyed this....some good shit!

16 oz. bottle courtesy of Neil.  Dark cola-like pour with a creamy head (oddly reminiscent of their root beer).  Sweet aroma of caramel and maple syrup.  Flavor of roasted malt, toffee, and dark chocolate.  If you asked me blindly to tell you what beer style this was I probably could not.  Sort of a cross between a dopplebock and a porter.  Not as sweet as a dopplebock and not as roasty as a porter.  Overall a very good beer.

Pours black with a little red tint at the edges with a quick fading head.  Aroma is roasted malts with some chocolate.  There is also some random cardboard scent.  Taste is chocolate up front with lots of roasty malts.  Not too complex.   Mouthfeel is pretty thin. Overall, not too bad, but I would question getting this again..

Dark almost black color. It pours cleanly with a low head that diminishes as quickly as it arrives. 

Smooth and sweet with a heavy caramel odor and flavor. It looks light almost lacking in the creamy frothy appeal expected in beer with such a reputation.
Pours black with reddish edges. Aroma is light roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is roasted malt, light chocolate, and a little bitterness.
Tap at Lenoras Way. Poured pitch black. Very mild nose. Body was light and drinkable,and Lightly carbonated, with malt flavors and some sweetness.

12 oz bottle from awiseman01. Pours a deep brown black with a bubbly light tan head. Aromas of malts mainly, light coffee. 
Flavors have some nice chocolate tones that go back and forth to coffee. A creamy milk chocolate. Full malt backing adds to the complexity. 
Mouth is nicely carbinated with a medium to full mouth. Medium length sticky finish. Mild bitterness. Great schwarzbier. Plenty of full flavor.

black pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of espresso, brown sugar, and loads of roasted malt. Flavor is very roasty, lots of malt, some nice bitter cocoa, and an espresso finish. Really interesting beer, but im not sure if its that true to the style. none the less, its awesome!
Sprechers best beer! Great full body, aroma, chewy fullness, rich creamy head. Cant drink a lot of them, so enjoy it slowly>

Pours a very deep reddish blackish sort of color with a big smei loose tan head and plenty o lace. The smell is intense with moleasses and just a little coffee. Ther e is a nice bitter hoppiness to this as well wich pairs well with an intense roasy almost burnt flavor rounded with a nuttiness. Pretty nice a little more complex and a hell of a lot less fruity than I remember from the last time I drank this.

bottle - Pours very dark brown with a one finger tan head.  It has a roast malt aroma with a small hint of chocolate.  Flavor is sweet roast malt with some chocolate notes up front and a lightly hopped finish that balances it out nicely.  Light to medium bodied with ample carbonation, its a good quaff.

Coming out of the bottle, this beer instantly captured my attention, man it was good looking.  Black, no real highlights, thick tan head, small tight bubbles, nice retention.  Roasted, and chocolate in the nose.  Yup a little coffee too.  Decent palate with a sharp start and nutty toasted end, also caramel.  A bit watery in the palate but to be expected in this style.  Very very good, Im guessing best schwarzbier Ive had.
Delicious dark thick brew.  Great opaque color and wonderful coffee choc flavors.  Increases in intensity when it slightly warms up.  Try it!!

Pours dark brown with mahogany edges. A large chunky tan head over the pour, has great retention and leaves some some lacing. Aroma is lots of roast, caramel, a decent amount of cocoa, char, and some herbal hop notes. Flavor is char, chocolate, some sweet grass, a little toffee, roast, caramel, black tea. Finish is char, burnt sugar, herbal hops, and light bitterness. Palate is medium thickness with a creamy entry, a slightly chalky finish and is slightly sticky. Pretty good

CHOCOLOT! Its BLACK its BAVARIAN BABY! thanks to G-money this beer was a reality tonight. Its Dark color n Choco/coffee n caramel accents were well balanced. This beer had an ok head with a powerful aroma! CHOCLOT!!!

Aromas of chocolate, roast, toasted nuts, and caramel. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head, some red highlights underneath. Flavors of chocolate and caramel initially. Roasted malts and coffee notes come in the finish and create a nice dry feeling on the palate. The beer then finishes lager clean with a nice crispness. Really nice and incredibly enjoyable.

Sampled on tap at the sprecher tour (glendale, wi). Pours a blackish pour with modwrate offwhite head. Aromas are lught sweet roasted maltiness balanced by a touch of creaminess. Taste is similar, roasted malt mixed with an underlying sweet creaminess that takes away and harshness. Balanced, nice body, sessionable. A winner!

16 oz bottle.  Deeeep opaque brown, with a small brown head.  A malty aroma with loads of fruit, candy sweetness, and licorice.  Malt and coffee and even some roast in the flavour.  Little bitterness.  On the thin side right out of the fridge, but it fills out as it warms.  A helluva lager.

Draft at Old Chicago Blaine MN.  Appearance was dark brown/black with some ruby overtones. Scent was definitely roasty with some dark chocolate. Taste was dark chocolate with some malt sweetness balanced with some endnote bitterness. No head or lace apparent. Mouthfeel was nice but not as much as I was expecting. Very good beer but frankly I was expecting more from the previous reviews.

Bottle from BD55. Thanks brian. Black in color, good sized head. Wierd aroma thats smells like wort in a homebrew.....Also a nuttiness. Taste was lots of chocolate, malty, light coffee touch. Overall taste was sweet. Texture was good, creamy and smooth. Overall for lager it was really good.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2012 Re-rate 7/23/11: Bottle. Beer of the month club. Almost opaque black color with a medium beige head. Nice roasted malt aroma with toasted bread, caramel, some nutty chocolate and some coffee. Sweetish flavor with roasted malt, caramel, coffee notes and a bitter herbal and roasty finish. Medium-bodied. A very good Schwarzbier. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

(11/8/08) Draught at a vegan restaurant called "Horizon" in Philadelphia. Dark brown color. Aroma of malt, some toastiness/roastiness, caramel, some chocolate and light nutty notes. Sweet flavor with toasted malt, caramel and mild noble hops bitterness in the finish. Medium-bodied. A well-made tasty Schwarzbier. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

16oz bottle.  Black with stained-glass colored edges.  Minimal white head.  Sweet, almost sugary.  Brown sugar, caramel, light smoke.  Minimal hops covered up, and way in the background.  Overall a pretty good Schwarz.  Fresh, and enough balanced dark malt flavor to keep it interesting.
16oz bottle.  Pours black with a 2 finger tan head.  Tons of roasted malt, smoke, and dried pit fruits on the nose.  Flavor had a touch of smoke, brew was medium in body, quite heavy for a lager.

Poured brown with ruby highlites and a fairly tall fizzy brown head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma of some light vinous fruits, some dark chocolate, a bit of roastiness, somewhat restrained.  Taste is lightly sweet with notes of dark fruits and some light roasty character.  Some watered down coffee in the flavor.  Body feels a little thin.  Not sure if Ive held on to it too long, but it feels a bit skeletal.  Perhaps Im expecting too much from a schwarzbier.

16oz bottle, surprised at the size. A black beer with a large tan head. The aroma is not super strong, but still very nice- malty chocolate, caramel, and sweet. The flavor is roasty, some sort of sour flavor, caramel, and also sweet chocolate. Nice creamy feel. Impressed, did not expect much from this brewer.

Pours "intensely dark" with almost no head.  Smell like burnt malty chocolate.  Tastes just like it smells, only better.  Creamy goodness.  It is really quite drinkable for being so "intensely dark."  Good stuff...

16 oz. bottle from Pristine Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Chocolate, woody, malty aroma...Pours black, almost no head. Flavor is nice woody, malty, and burnt...Very smooth on the palate, very drinkable. What a pleasant surprise...really really good. Like the 16 oz. bottles too...a little different.

Bottle.  Pours black with a small light tan head.  Aroma of rich bready malt and roasted lager malts with a slight hint of chocolate.  Flavor is quite similar, with a smooth palate.  Some vegetal notes with a sweet finish.  Not as roasty as some schwarzbiers are and its malt character reminds me more of a doppelbock.  A nice beer. 
7/4/7/4/15 (3.7/5)
Pours a dark brown with a foamy, medium tan head. A very moderate beer with hints of caramel, chocolate, coffee, and malts. Not as bitter as it may look; very drinkable.
thanks John! ... pours a dark as midnite ...good head ring .. dark roasty meaty smell like a hyenas bbq  .. i am digging this ... oily and easy to drink .. the abv works .. nice!
Bottle from New Beer.  Pours a dark brown black body with 1 finger creamy tan head.  Chocolate sweet malty aroma.  Creamy malty body with caramel and toffee.  A malty milkshake of enjoyment.
This reminds me of a really good porter.  A strong dark lager with a small tan head. I had this for the first time at JK O’Donnells. Goes very well with a filling meal. Great social drink

Bottle 16fl.oz. @ home.[ Trade by Papsoe ]. Clear medium to dark black color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, fully - mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, sweet dark bread, roasted, brown rye bread dough - sour bread dough, peat. Flavor is moderate to haevy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration. Bitternes is peat bitter, sweetness is brown sugar sweet. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. (030908)

22oz bomber. Pours a deep, dark black - but not opaque. Dark brown and ruby highlights shine through. The head pours thin and light, is short-lived, and leaves no lace. The aroma is dark toast breadiness and mild chocolate with some caramel sweetness. The flavor starts a little roasty like sweetened coffee - bready and toasty with a light roastiness that more closely resembles over-toasted bread than it does coffee. There is a strong caramel sweetness with a light, grainy malt tang. At mid-palate there is a fruity hop bitterness, strong roasted character, and stronger malt sweetness. The finish is mostly full with chocolate and coffee notes, a pleasant hop bitterness, and a balancing sweetness. The mouthfeel is crisply carbonated but sticky and thick in body. Overall - a pleasant black lager. It’s a bit big and roasty for Schwarzbier I think, but tasty nevertheless. Great for cool fall weather.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 Deep brown.... Slightly smoky, a hint of licorice, unsweetened chocolate, caramel.... This is the quintessential schwarzbier... I would have a hard time finding a porter i like better than this... This beer is amazing... No alcohol taste, thins as it finishes, incredibly complex...
Light aroma of real licorice; like dried wooden licorice root licorice.  Rich, malty flavor with more of that licorice root thing going on.
Pours dark with an amber hue and a medium tan head. Has a mild chocolate aroma and a light malty taste with a hint of bitterness. A little bland but not too bad.
pours dark brown with  creamy, thick head.  Aroma is malty sweet with espresso. creamy smooth palate. very drinkable

Pours black, mahogany.
Aroma, I cold not help but detect some very light smokyness. Malty and light fruits.
Taste, malty, smokey, with some very nice chocolate and grains. Some dark fruits (fig/cherry) and roastiness. 
Another great offering by Sprecher.
Solid brew. Aroma doesn’t do much, nothing off though. Flavor is chocolatey and sweet, fully of bites from the dark malt.

(Bottle).  Aroma is sweet and complex, lots of malt, roastiness, some chocolate.   Deep dark reddish-black body, creamy tan head.  Flavor a delicious blend of chocolate, malt, light roastiness.  Dry finish.  Superb.

I love this beer.  It has a color of dark chocolate along with a coffee/chocolate aroma.  Not bitter at all, in fact it has a touch of sweetness that leaves a lingering taste of cocoa powder on the palate.  Just delightful.

just happened across this as something different in a mix six pack from liquor loft here in tally.  nice little find.  black pour with a smallish creamy tan head and light bubbly lacing.  aroma of dark fruits and caramel.  rich creamy medium body.  lightly sweet roasted malts and dark bitter chocolate in the taste.  smooth and drinkable.  slightly acidic and tart on the aftertaste.  haven’t had many schwarzbiers to compare it to - but all around interesting.

Pours dark brown with a light brown head that starts big and settles to a thin froth.  Nose is full of roasted malt.  On the first sip the roasted malt is pleasant and not overpowering, continuing with an almost creamy flavor/texture, a touch of nuttiness and very mild coffee flavor.  Drinks smooth with small bubbles.  Finish is smooth and refreshing.  This one would be perfect to enjoy with a roast, and would even work to cook with.

Clear black pour.  Slight brown head that dissappated fairly quickly.  Pretty good roast malty aroma.  Good roast flavors, malt, nut, some coffee.  A bit of poundcake or something like that to make it solid medium bodied.  Soft mouthfeel almost creamy.  Roastiness lingers in the finish.  Has hints of stout/porter, but is neither all together.  A good black beer and very drinkable.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pint bottle.  Nice to find a US beer in a pint bottle.  Thin cream colored head, very flavorful aroma, full rich taste.  Deep and opaque, took the third sip before the coffee flavor made it’s appearance.  Very very nice.  I nice change from my normal porter/stout purchases.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2012 In short: An very satisfying session black lager that goes far beyond the raisins and roastiness of basic Swarzbiers
How: Bottle 22oz (beautiful black and gold bottle with waxed top).  Consumed very fresh a few days after purchase
The look: Very dark ruby (almost black) topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: Light-medium roastiness.  That cool doughy lager+cookie malts feeling.  Very nice pillowy body.  Some fruit cake, some dark caramel, some dark grapes, light chocolate presence, some Orio cookies.  More milk-chocolate as it warms up.  Not a very tasty but a very cohesive one where each element takes it place and makes for an overall extra satisfying dark lager.  Very nice offering.  Complex yet not very tasty, easy drinking, except for some German Neo-Nazi I cant believe anybody that cannot appreciate a Black Bavarian.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2008 Pours an epic obsidian black. An oatmeal tan head, fluffy and thick, rises authoritively above the body.  This beer looks lovely in a classic Schwarzbier style glass.  It smells fresh and roasty, complex and intriguing, with caramelly malt, milk chocolate, brown sugar, licorice, and dry, dark fruits.  There is a softness to the aroma, which is inviting and pleasant, almost gentle.  Yet when the first sip is taken, the soft aroma gives way to a very straight-forward, mocha-like taste, burnt and toasty, with raisins, cocoa, damson and plums.  However porter-like this might first seem, the mouthfeel gives way to a smooth, velvety creaminess, and ends crisp, satisfying and pleasantly bittersweet, reminding the drinker that this is in fact a lager, and a very impressive dark lager indeed.

Outstanding beer that delivers both sweet and bitter taste at the same time.  Very pleasant nose that smells faintly of chocolate and yet not a really an overdone scent.  Doesn’t linger on the palate, but not a thin finish either.  Well balanced and moderately drinkable, though probably not around a barbecue when it is 85 degrees outside.

draft. pours black with thin brown head. big roasted flavor, slightly nutty and bitter sweet. the palate was creamy but not too heavy. that said it took a while to put down a pint of it. so rich, its definitely a sipper. good.
I really love this beer. It’s nutty aroma, chocolate overtones, rich burnt coffee aroma, make this a complex and enjoyable finish to my day, Excellent1

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 Bottle, pilsner glass.  Pours dark brown, nearly black, with a thin tan head that disspates without leaving lacing.  Aroma of molasses, with a hint of raspberry.  Presents strong flavors of malt and molasses, with a touch of chocolate and the beginning.  Cola without the corn syrup.  Not viscous, but carbonation sparkles on the tongue.  Finishes with toasted barley with a tinge of bitter hops.  The lips and tongue become coated with a film that later provide a phenolic sensation and a complex group of long-lingering flavors, including chocolate, sourdough toast, bold coffee, and flowers.
Hell, wow.  Never know what to expect from black beers or Sprecher since my growler mishap, but impressed and enthralled.  Definitely would get this black bitch again.
Aroma is of roasted barley and full of bruntness with slight aroma of chocolate.  Palate is smooth and yet very full. Would buy again.

Tap at Redlight Redlight. Served in a half liter mug. Pours black with hints of red and a thick tan head. Roasty grain aroma with hints of smoky malt and chocolate. Tatse is smooth roasted grains, chocolate malt with a thick smooth mouthfeel. Finishes very clean, tasty.

Thick black pour with a fluffy tan head.  Intense molasses aroma with hints of caramel and chocolate.  Perhaps a bit of milk as well.  Chocolaty taste with lots of malt.  Very smooth and creamy.  Bitter with a little bit of maple syrup and slightly tart.

500 ml bottle from my secret santa. pours black with a nice tan head that lasts and lasts. aromas are of roasted malts. from the aroma im guessing crystal 80L and chocolate malts. flavours are caramel and chocolate malts. pretty thick in the mouth. suffers from a lack of hops but even still this is a damn fine schwarz.
I like the 16 oz bottles that is commonly comes in. It’s real dark, but easy to drink for a darker beer - bloating wasn’t an issue.
pours a dark black with a medium head aroma of dark chocolate and coffee. taste very sweet like a porter with light chocolate. not bad easy to drink

Near black in colour with a thin tan coloured head, good retention considering the size, good lacing.  The aroma has some chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, some sweetness.  The flavour is slightly roasty, chocolate and coffee come through, some caramel with a lingering sweetness throughout.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long with a coffee roast, sweet.
Everything seemed to pick up throughout this beer, what seemed boring at first turned out to be a very enjoyable.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with Optigon, thanks Gary.
Opened on February 16, 2008.
No date.

22oz bottle.  Nearly opaque brown-black with a small tight light brown head.  Pronounced chocolate aroma with tinges of roasty malt.  Coffee, bittersweet chocolate flavors dominate.  Tinges of earthy roast and smokiness.  Roast malt, toffee in the finish, with vestiges of smoke.  Mouthfeel is a light medium.

12oz gift from a RB guy from WI who came to the Alesmith Release.  Good to have a smokey beer, as my gf loves em.  Pours black with a 2 finger chunky light brown head.  Nose is malty and slightly smoked.  Taste is slightly smoky with sweet malts.   Tasty overall.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size diminishing tan head. Aroma of toasted caramel malt, chocolate, molasses, dark fruit and some smoke. Roasty flavour along with chocolate, light spices, light smoke, notes of coffee and hops. Average bitter finish. Medium to full bodied. A great beer, its well made and a pleasure to drink.

16 oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown/black with a tan/mocha head that quickly dissipates.  It looks like a stout or a dark porter, very attractive, much darker than most schwarzbiers I have come across.  The aroma is very pleasant.  It has a slight hint of coffee mixed with chocolate malt.  Very reminiscent of, again, a stout.  Flavor is mostly malt, with a slight touch of coffee in the aftertaste.  Lots of roasted notes, very easy to drink.  This is a good candidate for those "I dont like dark beer" people.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 Pours a nice dark brown with a thick creamy tan head that keeps a thin cap.
Aroma is coffee, nutty roast malt. light chocolate.
Nice roast malt sweetness and a little smokiness in the flavour, slight bitterness balances out the finish.
Very drinkable. 
At first I was pissed about four packs. I didnt realize till I got home that they were 16 oz bottles.
Had on tap. A dark beer that is very nice.  Aroma is slightly confusing, but tastes of malts, nutty, coffee, even smoke, but smooth and easy to drink.  Will drink again.

Bottled. Great Schwarzbier. Pours out clear black with a small tan head than dissolves into a ring. Busy aroma of smoke, chocolate, malt and some coffee. Very easy to drink with a mild, roasted flavour. Not overpowering at all.
Pours a deep black body with a medium sized tan head. full bodied, rich roasted malts and a nutty aftertaste. Has a unique mouthfeel, a very filling beer.

Bottle sampled with Mad_Indian. Pours dark with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted caramel and chocolate malts. The flavor is slightly sweet, chocolate, roast, caramel. Good for its style, but i found this brew to be generally thin and boring.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a pitch black color, with some reddish highlights. Thick carbonated foamy tan head. Decent lacing. Caramel aroma, and some smoke. Slight vanilla. Straightforward but good. Roasted malt flavors, chocolate, and lots of malt flavors, all well-crafted. Medium bodied, quite drinkable, and, most importantly, good with dessert.

Bottle sampled with stegosaurus. I cant believe this average rating. Dark rown pour with small tan head. Roasted coffee aroma. Roasted taste but very thin in the body but not a bad beer for its style but its no 3.75.

16oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malts, soy sauce, roasting, and burnt malts.  Poured very dark brown in color with a small brown head that disappeared immediately.  Opaque.  Flavor of burnt malts, roasting, chocolate, coffee, soy sauce, and a little licorice.  Medium body.  Lightly sticky texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Burnt malt finish.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2008 Wow.  Pour is engine oil black with thick tan head.  Nice lacing on the mug.  Aroma is of roasted barley and burntness.  There are also some notes of chocolate in the aroma.  Palate is surprisingly smooth yet so full of flavor.  Flavors include a perfect roasted character, nice malt bill, notes of chocolate, and hints of caramelized malts towards the finish.  This is a very good brew.  Would definitely buy again.

Pours  black with deep brown highlights and a nice tan/mocha head.  Earthy aromas of roasted malt, molasses & dough.  Flavor is similarly earthy with roasted malt, mild coffee and chocolate notes..lightly smoky with a bit of caramel & bread toward the end.  Finishes with a nice light bitter edge and the roast & smoke.

Toasted grain and candi sugar aroma. Pours black (duh) with a tan, everlasting head. Caramel Flavors and smells. Body and mouthfeel of a porter but finish is of roasted coffee malt like a stout. Need a little more complexity either way.

Long time coming for this rating of an American classic.  Fairly sparse fizzy beige head and dark muddy brown body.  Aroma of dark chocolate, plums, and some squash.  Rich dark roasted malt flavors with pleasant lager characters.  Moderately sweet and full-flavored with light, roasty bitterness and some soft acidity.  Very solid change of pace beer for when youre in the mood for something different.

Bottle. Pours almost black with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, toasted bread, and dark chocolate. Medium body, crisp. Roasted malt flavor with more caramel, toast, and coffee. Nice lingering smoky bitterness. Very nice. This is something I could drink everyday.

Aroma: Espresso, burnt sugar, licorice, and lumber/sawdust.

Appearance: Burnt coffee black with a deep purple tone. Creamy, light tan, latte-colored head with pretty, sparkly little bubbles.

Flavor: Coffee, charred malts, dark cocoa, and theres a kind of odd mineral taste that reminds me of snow or ice thats been in the freezer too long. Finish is nice and espresso bean-bitter. Peaty notes and vodka-like alcohol comes through as the beer warms. Pretty tasty.

Palate: A tad syrupy and rather heavy. Not particularly creamy or smooth, but not overwhelming.

Overall: Bold and complex, this is something that should be emjoyed one at a time. Would pair nicely with roast beef or a rare steak.
Dark brown with medium tan head.  Aroma of caramel, roasted malts, chocolate.  Creamy texture with flavors of roasted malts, chocolate and light caramel.  Pretty good for a Sprecher.

Absolutely, without a doubt a stellar beer. I had wanted to try this beer for a very long time and thanks to some generous traders, my wish was suddenly reality. Ive had a few beers from Sprecher. Most were average to above average so this, by far, is my favorite. 

The beer pours out a jet black liquid, a nice light brown two-finger thick head with some legs on it. Aroma that I was picking up was chocolate, coffee, caramel chews. Flavor left me wondering if this in fact wasnt some kind of stout. It had several of the same characteristics of a stout. Roasted/coffeeish malts, dark chocolate, and molasses. Mouthfeel was so smooth and clean. Somehow it just seemed light as air. Just superb.

Bottle, Very dark, nearly black. Not much head. Coffee-like aroma. Flavor is sweet at first, but a dark roastiness then comes through leaving a smoky aftertaste. Well-made beer, but Im not enthralled with smoke. Softly carbonated.
On draft at GL.  Pours a dark cola with a burgundy tint and a creamy medium sized beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, and baking chocolate.  Taste of roasted malt, baking chocolate and rust.

Pours black with a large creamy tan head..wonderful.  Large roasted chocolate malt aroma, with a touch of peat and coffee.   Mmmmm... this beer kicks-ass.    Sweet complex roasted maltiness.  Coffee, smoked peat and light chocolate - the trifecta.  The balanced and subtly really make it.  Light bodied, with the classic Sprecher light fluffy creaminess.  Great beer, quaffable indeed!

On tap at Mr.Goodbar 
Appearance:  Dark brown going into black. Creamy coffee like head. 4-Nose : Lightly roasted aroma , hint of quality beans and toasted grain.6+ Flavor/Palate : Medium , light bodied . slight sour charcoal like malts. Long lasting impression. Thin front with but finish was much better.

Pours wonderful from the 16 oz bottle.  Dark dark brown, almost black with a thich tan head, almost 1 1/2-2 in.  Smooth roasty aromas, with hints of light chocolate, very caramelly aroma.  Very rich roasted malt flavor, some bittersweet chocolate, hints of charcoal and smoke, extremely smooth flavors!  1 of if not the best swartzbier ive had!

bottle- real funky and undesirable smoke- bbq chicken like aroma immediately hit me. Thankfully, this subsided, but then the metallic c02 scents started coming up. I got past the aroma once I started drinking, and found this to be a pleasant roasty brew. At first, this tasted like a nice robust porter, and I was pleased. Some dark chocolate there too. The it warmed, and thats where the smoke started coming in. Not typical of the style, and not welcome. Probably would not seek this out again.

22, screw-capped and waxed. Thanks, Kim! Pours black with gentle rubied highlights in the corners. Lovely. Big nose of molasses, caramel, smoke, roast, and spent grain. Delicate medium body with very little, very fine carb. All the molasses, caramel, smoke, roast, and spent grain return for the mid-palte, before washing into a brief nutty finish. This is the kind of lager that could convince me to drink a lot more lagers. The bodys definitely nowhere near as big and satisfying and comforting as an ale of this color, but the cleanliness of it has a magic all its own.

Bottle with thanks to Ofortuna, and my first Schwarzbier!  Pours a dark brown with a two finger creamy tan head that lingers quite a while, minimal lacing.  Aroma is roasty and sweet, with caramel, toffee, to a much lesser extent, some coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is malty and also a bit sweet, with more caramel, toffee and a bit of cola.  Very quaffable, but not really my thing.  Thanks again David!
Pours a dark dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, some caramel, and some roastiness. Nice  flavor, drinkable, good stuff.

Bottle thanks to Ty5592.  Poured a deep black color with a thick, creamy tan head that slowly faded and left nice lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, light caramel and coffee, a hint of roast and lager yeast.  Smooth, light chocolate entry with undertones of caramel and a nice malt character.  A bit of light hops and a drying, chalky finish.  My description isnt doing it justice, but it is a very tasty beer.  Smooth and easy to drink, definitely better than I anticipated.  Thanks Ty!
Sweet, toasty with malty caramel notes. This beer presents itself with a reddish, dark body and a two finger, tan head.  Nice mouthfeel. A pretty complex schwarzbier. I could drink a couple of these.

16oz. brown bottle served in a pilsner glass. Poured a deep brown/black with about a finger of fine bubbled white head. Lots of chocolate and cocoa in the aroma. Rich body with plenty of roasted malt bitterness. Long dry coffee finish. Great complexity, bold flavors. Good stuff.
very good beer.  Poured a deep black with a nice tan head on it.  Thought it was going to be bitter at first but to my surprise it wasnt.  Very drinkable

16 oz bottle.  Pours a dark, deep brown, looks like a stout or a porter!  Slight tan head.  Aroma is malty and a bit like toast.  The flavor is an incredible combination of malt, chocolate, and coffee notes, with a bit of caramel.  Mouthfeel is slightly slick and thinner than I expected, and a bit effervescent.  Overall I would highly recommend this beer.

Stumbled across a 4-pack of 16 oz. bottles, and inside of the bottles surely is a thing of beauty. Rich, deep brown pour with a thick lasting tan head and ample lacing. Dang thing looks like a stout. Malty aroma that is roasted, bitter, and sweet. Filling brew, nice and smooth on the palate. Robust and extremely drinkable. Flavor is packed with toasty malt and roasted nuts. A touch of chocolate and brown sugar. Floral hops that add a balancing bitter taste. An all around exceptional beer, incredible lager.

Clear black body with a large frothy light brown head. Huge malt and chocolate aroma, some light molassas. Huge chocolate and roast flavor, light molassas and hints of caramel. Medium full body with moderate carbonation and a smooth roasty finish.

Look - Looks like a stout or porter. Black in color with a tan head.

Smell - Espresso/coffee smell. Bitter. Very good.

Tast - Espresso/coffee taste. But very mild. Could pass for a stout. Goes down smooth but the espresso/coffee taste linger which isnt bad. Very good. This is an unusual yet really good style that Ive never had before.
very dark on the pour. A nice sweet, malty aroma. Slightly fruity, coffee/chocolate and a almost toasty dryness at the end. Makings of a good roast, or chili beer, would also work for dessert.

Bottled, 2007.  Wow, shockingly good.  Pours very dark with a slightly reddish hue and a moderate head.  Significant lacing. Roasted malts aroma. Taste is chocs and caramels, very light mouthfeel.  Hint of bitter to finish. Great beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2014 500ml bottle.  Proper dark brown/near-black color, with a small tan head, creamy and luscious.  Decent roast, smoke, jerky and char in the nose, but not quite like stout, and not quite like most other schwarzbier Ive had - theres some fruit/berry aspects as well, and some candy sugar note too, which is strange.  Flavor is crisp, moderately thick,  creamy over the middle, with some light wood dry (but not dry), some toast, some chocolate malt and some sweeter chocolate syrup.  A small soapy note pops up when warmer, but altogethor its a nice beer, very drinkable.

16 oz bottle thanks to tjthresh, Thanks man. Well keeping on with my "S" breweries day I lucked into this beer TODAY from a trade, this is the 4th of the night and what a suprise!! Pours a nice deep brown body with orange edges and a large beige head. Aroma of sweet bakers chocolate, floral notes and bread. Light bodied with slight carbonation that is highly drinkable. flavor of bitter chcolate, and hmm malts?? Sure yeah malts that works. Bottom line, good beer, slightly buzzed rater.
Dark black color with little head. Aroma is a strong whiff of chocolate syrup and port. Palate is a little flat. Toasty smooth flavor with hints of alcohol and espresso finish.

Bottle from a trade. Thanks whoever sent this.  Pours a dark hazelnut with a small tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, ash, and coffee. Flavor is a little more muted with more chocolate and a mild hoppy thing.  Pretty good, I think I liked the Kidd Lager better.

The top rated schwarzbier on tap at the brewey, alright, here we go.  Dark brown almost black, with creamy tan head and lacing.  Smoky and roasty aroma very light.  Smoky sweet roasted malt with cherry, oh so good.  Medium body and well carbonated.  This is a very good beer.
Sprechers best. Great appearance. Wonderful pour and head. Good character. Not too hoppy. Great roasted flavor and licorice flavor. Good beer.
A very dark complex flavored beer. All dark, dark, dark. Roasted malts, dark chocolate, Earthy flavors. A very interesting beer.

Poured coffee black. Really not impressed by this beer. Very weak aroma and taste. The flavor that is detectable is bland and nothing that great. Maybe I had a bad bottle or maybe this beer is average at best??

The bottle I had did not look like the picture to the left. Pours black with smokey roasted caramel aroma and taste. Had some light bandaid notes but not too bad. Light sweetness and very enjoyable. Better than I thought it would be. Well made.
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 not a bad beer for a guy who use to work for pabst, this is a very big bold beer, a little on the bitter side  but still i always go back for more a gret american brewery

pours black and opaque, light tan head without bubbles more like a crust, excellent lacing, aromas of coffee and chocolate, thinner than expected on palate, heavt coffee flavors mid to long duration.... on tap at Old Chicago Plymouth
a little coffeeish, very dark. Nice Tan head. Less carbonation than some others. Good Not great but good.

Wax-dipped bomber.  Dark black beer, thin tan head.  Very rich aroma.  Toasted caramel and molasses, clean cold coffeeish character as well.  Fairly complex maltiness with cocoa, toasted rye and a lovely well-lagered character.  Lightly smoky and a bit salty.  Rich palate, a bit rummy with heavy caramel and coffee.  Excellent.

16 oz. bottle in trade with ketchepillar- poured into my trusty stein- poured black, light tan formed and slowly dissolved away like in a Dali painting.  Aroma of slightly roasted malt, sugar, molasses, and coffee. Hits the mouth with a great medium body, elements of smoke, malt, coffee, and dark chocolate from start to finish, which is solid.  Now this is beer!!!

bottle provided by indra... cola colored pour with a quickly disappearing reddish brown head. aroma is woody, molasses, black raisins, sweet malt and banana like lager yeast. the flavor is quite similar...its got a salty element to it along with a light ashiness in the malts and some chocolate. the finish is acidic followed by ashiness. no aftertaste to speak of. body and texture are medium but richer considering the style. it smells and tastes like a baltic porter with a thinner body. quite a complex brew!

16 oz bottle. Dark brown, some deep red highlights. Tight beige head. Big, rich, sweet malt nose, toffee and a bit of smoke. Complex malt flavors, mild coffee and a touch of charcoal. Smooth medium body. A touch of bitter chocolate comes through in the finish. Excellent.

Pours a dark opaque chocolate brown with a minimal amount of beige head. Aroma is malty with undertones of smoke, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is of coffee and chocolate with hints of caramel sweetness. Very smooth taste. Not a bitter aftertaste with a bit of carbonation that lightens the body. Another good beer by Sprecher.

Bottle. Dark red/brown almost black body with a small beige head. Looking great. Moderat malty aroma. Flavor is gentle roasted malt, some caramel, otherwise quite clean malt flavor. Not much bitter, light, refreshing and harmonic but Im not exactly impressed.

Bomber.  Pours black yet pretty thin. The foamy tan head disappears quickly, and when held up to direct light, red highlights come through making this not opaque..but beautiful! Initial whiff reminds of a wet dog on summer day. Strange. Nose develops into a celebration of malts; peat smoked, roasted, chocolate, woodsy notes, followed by hints of coffee, vanilla, and a squeeze from a lemon wedge. Light and thin mouth feel but not lacking flavor. Coffee, chocolate, and some muted caramel malt are first to come through in the flavor, followed by notes of prunes, smoke, and molasses. Finish is lightly hopped and a touch tart citrus. Really interesting brew.

Bottle.  Pours black with dark red hues when held to light.  Dense light brown head.  Chocolatey aromas.  Rich coffee and chocolate flavors.  Creamy palate.  Decent beer, but I thought they were supposed to be more akin to pilsners.
A nice dark pour, with a brownish-tan head. The aroma is a nice coffee-chocolate malt. The taste is a creamy and mild mix of the same. I like this and will be buying it again.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a diminishing tan head.  Aroma is lightly chocolate, coffee, caramel, and some smokiness from the wood fires.  The taste is light chocolate, coffee, caramel, with a hint of smokiness.  It is so smooth in terms of taste and mouthfeel that you could easily take down a 4-Pack.  Very enjoyable brew.  Well done.

Poured from a 16oz bottle and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a rich black color with some mahogany highlights around the edges of the glass.  A one-finger thick head of tan foam faded into a thin layer of small, lasting bubbles.  No lace.  The aroma of this beer was made up of rich caramel notes, chocolate, and a light smokiness.  The flavor consisted of an abundance of balanced malts.  Notes of chocolate, coffee, and caramel all intertwined seemlessly with a hint of dark fruit sneaking in towards the end.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with light carbonation.  The flavor of this beer was exceptionally balanced and smooth, making it a great session choice.  Well done!
Enjoyable flavor. Not too overwhelming for a black style beer. A good flavor and a nice relaxing drink.
Bottle from the First Houston TastingPours deep black with an aroma of banana.  Molasses and sugar take center stage in the flavor theater.  Average mouthfeel.  Overall, a great brew.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours black, thin head.  Flavor is roasts, chocolate, smoke, molasses.  Creamy and smooth.  Very good.  Much better than I was expecting.

Trade with beerlando.  The color was dark chocolate.  The head was creamy, off-white, and thin.  The aroma was soy sauce, molasses, smoke, and sweet malt.  The flavor was smokey, burnt, molasses, sweet malt, and some coffee.  The palate was smooth.  The finish was long-lasting and smokey.

Trade with beerlando. Nice dark pour with a one finger tan head that fades quickly. The aroma shows some coffee, definitely malt rich, caramel, and some choco.The flavor is rich and malty, coffee, earthy, molasses, a bit burnt, definitely German notes. The palate is fairly carbonated. Finishes well and leaves a coffee like taste in your mouth.

Probably the darkest lager that Ive ever seen, it pours jet black and is almost completely opaque with a dense, creamy, dark tan head that reduces to a thin skin of tan bubbles. Nice patchy lacing. The nose is of roasted malt: chocolate, light coffee and a faint toffee. Medium-bodied and slick with a clean roasted finish, the flavor is of roasted chocolate malt with notes of caramel and faint coffee. This is a very tasty beer and is easily my new favorite lager, in any style. I hope that Sprecher starts distributing in Missouri soon.

bottle at Houston Beer Tasting.  Pours opaque with very thin off-white head.  Interesting roast malt aroma.  Taste surprised me!  This had chocolate, coffee and roasted flavor with texture unexpected from a lager.  This was a lager that wanted to be a porter!  And I like porters.

From the bottle, it pours black, seeming almost without any carbonation whatsoever, with a small, dense, light bornw head that steadily dissipated to a thick ring.  The aroma is a rich roasted earthy chocolate and coffee with other less clear elements.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but lighter than first expected.  It has definite coffee, chocolate, toasted malt, and even some flowery/spice elements, with a nice blend of sweet and bitter.  The flavour is strong and lasting, but light and exceedingly smooth.  It is more carbonated than it first appeared and it has a pleasant, lively yet creamy palate.  It is rich and satisfying without being heavy and is light, delicious, and exceedingly drinkable.

First Official Houston Tasting. Thanks to BigGreen (BA) for bringing this. Great dark pour with garnet glints and a very thin edge-head. Aroma of nicely roasted malts with chocolate, clove and licorice. Very nice porter-like taste with cocoa and cooked sugar in the flavor. Creamy mouthfeel with a wonderful roasty finish. Truly enjoyed this beer.

Bottle received via trade with Beerlando.  Pours black with a spare, rocky and bubbly light brown head, somewhat lasting with spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, bread, toasted grain), light hops (herbs), average yeast (dough, leather) with notes of charcoal and brown sugar.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a chalky finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.  Nice lightly roasted malt flavor with hints of chocolate.

16 oz. bottle. Pours out a gorgeous black/brown, creating a medium/small tan head.  It has an aroma of heavy thick malt with no detectable hops at all. Tastes of coffee, burnt caramel and molasses.     Once again very heavy malt flavor with very little hops. It is smooth and has a nice mouth feel. Overall flavor is lightly sweet but good.  As it warms up the burnt caramel/molasses flavor becomes much more prominent.  Overall this is a nice beer that I will try again.

Pours a dark blackish brown with thin creamy head.  Toasty aroma of coffee. again coffee in flavor with a bitter bite.  Leaves a smoky trail. A bit one dimensional but very good for what it is.  Taste is more like a Porter than a Schwarzbier.

Bomber.  Dark brown/black color with a thin beige head.  Rich dark roast malt aroma of chocolate and toffee, like a goumet candy-creme. Some traces of espresso.  Dark and robust mocha java flavor with some earthy charred wood/leaf notes on the finish.  Nice roasty bitterness to complement the dark richness of the malts.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation.  Very enjoyable.
pours very dark brown,almost black thin off white head,malty,roasty nise,malty sweet chocolate taset very nice.very much like a porter nice.will buy again!!!!!!!

Bottle.  Pour dark brown. Almost no head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is dark fruits and lots of malt.  First sip is a roasted, smokey, chocolate, and a bit of coffee.  Some light hops peek through at the end and help give it a more robust flavor.  Somewhat thin, light smooth feeling on the tongue.

(Can, thanks OSLO and Guerde) Pours very dark brown. Roasted and malty aroma with tones of chocolate, coffee, hay, burned caramel and hints of smoke. Undertones of herblike hops, raw potatoes, gravel, dark bread syrup and fruits like pears, raisins, and apricots. Maybe some tiny notes of cheese doodles. Roasted malt flavour of dark bread, coffee, caramel and chocolate. A bit smoky in the flavour as well.  Herb-ish and light grassy hops in the background. Hints of prunes and gravel. Light to medium sweet and light bitter. Thin, a bit sour and light velvety mouthfeel. Light to medium bodied.

This beer pours a really dark brown almost black with no head at all. this lager has a really nice aroma of pitted fruits and mild hops with tons of malt. As you drink it the initial taste is very smokey with lots of caramel on the sides of your mouth as well as mild chocolate on the palate which lasts for a good amount of time. I personally like the carbonation miked with the fruits on the tip of your tounge.

This is a truly complex malty lager. The aroma is of rich, roasted malts with notes of smoke and wood (vanilla) along with some grahm cracker and nougat overlain. The flavour is a complex meadly of dark pitted fuits, sweet caramel, mild chocolate, coffee, and smoke with a subtle hop presence. The mouthfeel is slick on the body and fizzy on the carbonation. The finish is long and sticky, as the bittersweet black liquid coats the palate and lips. EPIC!

Bottle poured a clear black with ruby highlights and a small diminishing amber head. Aromas of carmel, chocolate, light vanilla and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, smoke, roasted malt and light chocolate with a crisp lingering malty finish.
Almost no head. Very sweet aroma & flavor. Still, a somewhat bitter finish. Tasty yet by the end the sweetness became a bit too much.

Tap at Brewtopia 2007: Deep brown pour with a nice dense tan head that lasts. Nice roasted malt aroma with a hint of oats, dark cocoa and a very subtle roasted coffee touch. Creamy feel on the medium body with a great dark malt flavor. Theres tons of character without being sweet at all, rather it has a dark chocolate richness with a roasted coffee touch in the mildly bitter finish. This is well made stuff.

The beer has a beautiful color, but unfortunately, it is waaay off the mark for the style.  Schwarzbier should neither be hop bitter nor have an aromatic hop nose.  This beer has both in abundance.  There is no such beer even remotely similar to this in Bavaria.

Bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar.  Dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasty with notes of band aid.  Satin smooth palate.  Dark chocolate and coffee taste.  Except for the one flaw in the aroma, this beer is quite good overall.

Pours opaque with foamy brown head.  WOW!!  This was a surprise.  Hoppy sweet fruity with lots of roast, coffee, and no strange flavors.  Very nice!   I dont know the style at all, but I LOVE this brew.  More smooth and refined than one would expect.

In the aroma, I find a very roasty and dark malt complexion that has me curious how its going to taste. Well, it too (the flavor) has a rich and roasted malt character and is quite fizzy with carbonation to make for an interesting drink. Pitch black liquid with a tanned topping of head.

Mind you when you find the best it is only the best till you have better. I have yet to have better. Again schwarzbeirs are my bread & butter but I rate for the style on each rating not personal favorites.
 HOLY S***!!!!!! what a good beer & I cant even have it on draft!  But it still lays waste to every black beer I have had, draft or otherwise.
 I live in SC. & have a buddy in WI that brings it when he can.
 A PERFECT example of what this style is all about!!

Solid black body with hints of chestnut brown at the edges when held to a light source.  Small, foamy, light tan head settles relatively quickly to a small rim.  Minimal spotty, sudsy lacing dots the glass.  The nose is comprised of rich caramel, nougat, and chocolate malts, accompanied by indiscernible dark fruits and hints of vanilla.  The flavor shows lightly roasted chocolate malts, caramel, nougat, and lightly oaked vanilla.  There is minimal hop bitterness, though the oak adds a sharpness that helps to balance out the sweet malts.  Medium-full body with a substantial, slick mouthfeel.  Short chocolate finish.  Incredibly flavorful for a Schwarzbier.  Resembles an Old Ale in many ways.  Very solid.

12oz bottle. pours dark w/ fizzy small tan head that didnt last long at all. sorta looks like cola. nose isn tmuch but some coffee and roast. flavor is roasty, stale coffee. mouth feel is light and fizzy. over carbonated. i never liked this beer on tap and i dont like it bottled. cant figure out the high ratings, maybe it has gone down hill over the years.

16oz bottle.  Pours a Guinness-like thick, cloudy black with a mocha-colored head.  Aroma is twofold with a strong stout-like bouquet of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, and coffee alongside a subtler lager-like aroma of earth and yeast.  Body is medium and tart with an initial bitterness giving way to flavors of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt.  A truly wonderful schwarzbier that shows a great deal of complexity.
Nice black pour with small amber head.  Aroma strong of chocolate and coffee.  Taste matches aroma but mouth is a little thin.

16 oz.bottle.  Pours black with deep ruby highlights.  Decent sized tan head.  The aroma is mediumsweet with good roasted malt character, caramel, and chocolate.  The flavor is much of the same with the roasted and chocolate malts blending nicely.  There is mild bitterness to balance the medium sweetness.  Smooth medium body.  A solid schwarzbier.
Bottle.  Aroma is of coffee and sweet malt.  Black/brown body with a tan head.  Malty and lightly sweet flavor.  Watery soft.  Good all around.  Good porter like taste without the any bitterness.
From a bottle at Woodmans.  Nice black pour.  Flavors of chocolate and roasted malts plenty of creaminess

Pours black with a small light tan head.  Oily looking.  Smells of big dark fruits, dark malts, berries, and maybe even the slightest touch of chocolate.  The taste is much the same.  Big dark fruity taste with a huge malt presence.  I get some of that mild chocolate flavor in the finish and lingering into the aftertaste.  Seems to be balanced quite well.  Very solid schwarzbier.

Bottle. Thanks to Stine for sending me this gem. Pours a deep black body with nice head. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt. Flavor has a deep roastiness to it, some chocolate, caramel and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. This went down too quick and found myself forgetting this was a lager and not a porter. Good beer.
Bottle poured a dark brown color with a nice light tan head. Aroma was chocolate, roast, caramel and toffee. The flavor was super clean with chocolate and caramel standing out the most. Very nice.
Pours a coca cola black with a 2 finger khaki head. Coffee, chocolate and roastedness on the nose. Flavor is ht esame with hints of caramel.Finish was coffee bitterness.

Bottle; poured a dark brown-almost black.  Minimal head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor initially slightly sweet, but that fades away.  Some light bitterness, with most of the flavor being roasted malt and chocolate.  Almost tasted like a porter.  Good for the style.

This is a dark, dark lager. The head is extrememly this and was gone almost as soon as it appeared. This beer smells like a lager, but with a hint of cloves or some other spice in the background. This beer has a thick, malty flavor. There may be some chocolate and coffee in the background as well. The flavor almost adds a creamy texture to the beer. Dark lagers arent my favorite, but for a dark lager this is a pretty great beer. It might be just a little sweet for my liking, but other than that its pretty tasty.

Dark brown, nearly black color with a medium head.  Aroma is pleasantly malty with some roasty grain, coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor is a really nice roasty grain with some nice hop bitterness, chocolate, and coffee.  Somewhat porterish, but very unique.  Ive never had a schwarzbier this good, and can see why its tops in style.

12oz bottle.  Almost black in color, thin deep brown head.  Sweet smell of dark roasted malts.  Nice thick mouth feel with a lasting aftertaste, but not too heavy.  Sweet at first and then a little bitter, with a persistent taste of the dark roasted malts.  Good desert beer.

(16oz bottle) Received in a trade wit Ughsmash. Pours a thin, creamy beige head with an opaque body. Nose of rich coffee grounds. Nice creamy smooth cocoa and coffee flavour. Very oily and tasty. Great stuff.

This is probably the best lager Ive ever tasted. The color is an oil black with amber hints. The color hints at a full-bodied beer, but this is more medium-bodied than similar looking ales. But the aroma and tastes of coffee, roasted malt, and even a hint of chocolate remind me more of a porter than any lager Ive ever tasted. This is a surprisingly good beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear very dark brown with ruby highlights and a large long lasting rocky tan head that leaves great lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and caramel. Taste is coffee, roasted malt, and light caramel. Medium full body with a well balanced bitterness. Heavy for a Schwarzbier and more like a full flavored Porter but still very good.
Bottle Chris_o Shindig.  Dark lager, pretty good.  Good hop.  Nice enough and my penultimate beer of the day.
Rich, dark roasted maltiness, with chocolate-coffee finish. Substancial body.

This beer came in my beer club - I am not familiar with the brewer. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bark black color with a large dark brown head. The aroma was roasty and bitter with a floral hop presence and a hint of coffee. The flavor was roasty, bitter and had a light coffee element. The finish was long and bitter.

Poured dark brown with plenty of ruby highlights.  The head was tan, compact and somewhat creamy.  Some lacing.  The aroma was lots of smoky, roasted malt.  Some thin chocolate.  Coffee too.  The flavor was smoky malt and coffee.  A somewhat succinct finish.  Fairly heavy body for a schwarzbier.

Bottle. Deep brown pour with a small head. Flavor is roasted dark malt, a little chocolate and a bit of smoke. Moderately sweet with a light, bitter note. Medium body. Amazingly easy to drink. Well done.

text: Tasted at http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eventID= with DenverLogan, and Quaff members.  1yr old bottle I believe.  Black color.  Mild flavor.  Not memorable.

16 ounce bottle
I have had a few of these and figured it was about time to rate it.  Coming from Sprecher my expectations were not that great but this was a pleasant surprise.  It didnt blow me away but it was not found totally lacking as most of their beers are.  This may be the sort of thing that I would pick up occasionally for a change of pace.
Aroma / Appearance - A fluid dark brown body swirled around the glass.  A sandy thin head sat on top for a few minutes then began to fade into the rest of the liquid.  Smoky malts, black coffee and the dregs of a pot of coffee.  It was pretty plain but that is typical for most schwarzbiers I have tried so far.
Flavor / Palate - A thin mouthfeel coated the mouth in a bit of smoke and dark fruits.  Toffee and slight bitterness reminded me somewhat of a sweet stout without the roasted malts.  The figgy dry finish makes a strong impression before it fades.  It could be more complex but it is still pretty satisfying.

Bottle. Pours nearly pitch black w/ hints of ruby coming through when held up to the light. Very small brown head. Aroma is dark chocolate with just a hint of fresh coffee beans. Some sticky caramel in the aroma, too. Flavor is smooth maltiness, faint coffee flavor, vanilla and some earthy notes. Not at all sweet, well balanced. Light coffee-like bitterness in the finish. Round, creamy mouthfeel. Not my favorite style, but a great beer nonetheless.

(bottle) Pours a very dark brown with a tan head that reduced quickly to a ring around the glass.  The aroma contained some roasted coffee and a hint of chocolate.  Flavor was mainly coffee, with a nice smoky finish, quite good.

[Bottle] Pours dark brown with a quickly disappearing small dark tan head.  The aroma was mainly coffee with hints of smoke.  The taste was once again coffee and smoke, with a little bit of roasted malt.  The coffee came through stronger as it warmed.  Medium mouthfeel.  Nice long finish.  Good beer.

16oz bottle, courtesy of Ughsmash.  Thanks, Jason!  Pours a very dark brown appearance; medium tan head with excellent retention and lacing.  Chocolate and smoked meats in the aroma, with a hint of bitter coffee.  Medium-to-full, roasted and (surprisingly) smoky mouthfeel: the smoke character is rather spicy, almost like a Slim Jim or beef jerky, but in a beer form; the closest similarity I can think of is HOTD Adam, although thats a heck of a lot more dense and less sessionable; excellent roasted coffee and chocolate creaminess coming through mid-palate, taking over where the initial smokiness and spice leave off; dense, generous, and damn good.  Theres some buttery warmth poking through at the very end, leading into a creamy, buttery and smoked meat finish.  Excellent stuff.

Black body thin tan head which faded away fast.  A nice coffee like aroma, with some sweetness to it and a slight smoky note to it.
Flavor was that of burnt coffee, but pleasant.Some smoky cocoa notes in the finish.  The flavor does linger.  Palate was alright, but it seemed to be a little flat.  Good beer.

A favorite black lager.  Quite dark with little head..  aromatic chocolate aroma with a lingering mild coffee bitter finish.  On the sweet side for a black lager.  Excellent for a cold winter night.  Best on tap of course.
From the bottle pours dark brown with very little head.  Nice smokey malt flavor, with a lingering aftertaste.

(16 oz. bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>OhioDad, thanks Scott!) Black and malty...Pours very dark brown with a tall creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty, much like a doppel (molasses, raisins and hay) with the addition of chocolate.  Mouthfeel full and smooth, a touch dry. Nice lacing although a little patchy. Flavor is fairly rich and malty - bakers chocolate with molasses, raisins, hay and hints of honey. Loved it - the best one of this style I have had - but thought it maybe could be a tad richer.

A beautiful dark brew with a light, tan/creamy head. An aroma of malts and caramelized sugars. The palate is of semi-sweet chocolate mingling with caramelized malts and a hint of coffee notes lurking in the background. A good, home-grown Wisconsin brew.
A beautiful almost black color with a tan head. Aroma of malt and fruits. Make sure the beer is not too cold. The most complex flavors are at about 55 degrees.

Courtesy of Ofortuna: Nice deep black pour with no head. Aroma of roasted malt and darkness. Taste of mostly roasted malt with some caramel and chocolate in the aftertaste. Very thin mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Almost tastes like a porter with less carbonation and thinner mouthfeel. Good beer.
