text: Pours dark with no head. Aroma is dark malty, slighty toffee, dried fruit. Flavour is malty, roasted, toffee, dried fruit. Very dry overall.
blackish brown body, lighter brown edges.  thick foamy dark tan head.  aroma is light roasted chocolate malt.  flavor is roasted caramel malt, a little nutty and grassy.  mildly dry finish.

(Bottle) Pours an opaque brown color with a small, fizzy tan head. Solid aroma of roasted coffee and light cocoa. Flavor includes light burnt caramel and hazelnut as well. Moderate bitterness imparts a dry finish. Rich mouthfeel, yet extremely drinkable. A pleasant surprise from Sprecher!

pours black (no shit) with minimal head.  aromas are coffee ground, burnt caramel, smoke, and a light creaminess.  taste is very roasted with slight toffeeness.  mid taste the beer develops a certain tangy-ness along with mild sweetness and smoothness hard to describe.  finish is tart and smoky with a little mineral note.  very good stuff.

Wonderful aroma, Malt, a nice rich coffee, and earthy undertones.  Appearance did it for me, Im a sucker for a thick dark beer with a nice tan head.  Overall a great beer, definitely one Ill be drinking more of.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark, rich, oily brown with the faintest amber highlights. Great nose: roasted malt, smoked (almost burnt) wood, peat, roasted coffee.... very nice. Full and rich on the palate. A little weaker flavor than expected given the intense complexity of the nose. Still quite nice though. Full bodied and rich with the roasted malt shining through.

Bottle in Milwaukee.  I thought this was an excellent schwarzbier.  Probably a little fuller in malt flavor than the Kulmbacher schwarzbier-- wh ich I also liked.  Definitely rich and full in taste and body-- would like to try sometime on tap.

4/23/2007:  Sprecher Black Bavarian pours out a milk chocolate brown color.  The beer looks pretty clear on the pour, but opaque in the glass.  The head is average in size and is foamy, somewhat puffy in texture, and mocha in color.  I leaves layer-like lacing and the residual crown looks like coffee does when the cream is first poured in...  The aroma contains dark roasted malts, deep caramel, and maybe some complex fruit characteristics.  The flavor is roasted malt and dark chocolate (Dutch cocoa) with some slight charcoal hints.  The finish has a  roasty cocoa flavor.  Overall the beer has an equaling bitterness that balances this beer nicely.  The body is nearly full and the texture/mouthfeel is creamy and amazingly smooth (tiny carbonation bubbles).  Specher Black Bavarian is super easy to drink with great roastiness and complexity in the flavor.  It would be quite easy to drink the entire 4-pack of this in one sitting!

16 oz bottle (33962 FL 070721159) from Jungle Jims; 5.8% ABV.

12 oz.  Dark, sweet, mild/smooth roast, easy. Perfect example of style. Beer of the month club offering.

On tap. Very smooth roasted cocoa and caramel flavors. Easy to drink. Definitely a good "session" beer, due to the lower abv and creamy quaffability. Probably Sprechers best offering, which is impressive considering their fine lineup.

Dark brown pour with ruby highlights and a nice tan head.  Incredible aroma, very roasty with burnt coffee and caramel.  Creamy mouthfeel, carbonation is perfect.  Coffee and licorice up front.  Slight hop bitterness towards the middle with more coffee, roasted dark malts.  Finish is smooth, bitter and has the lightest touch of smoke.  Excellent!  And its a lager!

This beer poured the darkest shade of brown you can get before it turning to black. Deep dark mahogany edges where the light actually manages to fight its way through. A 1 finger creamy mocha cap sits up top after the pour and fades down to a solid creamy cap. This beer looks relly nice on the pour.

Bottle. Red black colour with a beige head. Aroma is dry, sweet, roasted, coffee, caramel, smoked, hop. Ordinary, but ok beer.

A very pleasant surprise. thanks craig.
Poured a dark blackish brown with a khaki head.  Had a great aroma with malts and carmel and a bit of chocolate.  Well balanced with a slight bitterness on the finish.
on tap at the oasis in Rockford. Brown head that lasted, burnt carmel taste, but baanced, I didnt think the finish was all that dry.  A keeper.

Bottle (thanks Ughsmash).  Pours a dark brown with a sizable tan head - looks like a glass of Coke.  Muted aroma of malts and coffee.  Very easy drinking.  Tastes of caramel, malts and a little chocolate.  Slight hop bitterness on the finish.  Nicely balanced, nothing over-powering.  Not exactly sure what I was out of this one, but I am glad I tried.  Will look to pick a few more of these up!

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Pours a black brown from the bottle, a creamy tan head with lots of creamy lacing, rich roasted malt with faint chocolate and coffee aromas on the nose, hint of vanilla, there are whiffs of a wood fire to this beer, not quite smokey, maybe dark roasted malt or almost burnt malt?  This is not a negative but added to the dark roasted malt aroma, some licorice in the nose to, lots of roasted malt flavors with bitter chocolate and a touch coffee grain tastes, some sweet and faint caramel taste, dry palate in the finish, good tasty beer.

Bottle. Dark, chestnut color and a small tan head. Lightlty roasted aroma with a weak cofffee note and some honey notes. Dry and roasted in the mouth, with coffee and a medium body. Dry finish as well, with burnt notes. A cross between schwarzbier and stout was my first though on this one. (070427)
UPDATED: MAY 11, 2007 one of the more popular sprecher beers.  has a nice dark color and smells of caramel and coffe. great with cheese curds.

One of my favorite lagers here. Dark and opaque pour with a small tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of caramel and chocolate malts and spicy and fruity hops. Creamy carbonation enlivens the medium body. Taste echoes the aroma, with some roasty notes jumping into the caramel and chocolate backbone. Hop bitterness seems floral. Very nice!

Pours a lighter black color with a tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, molasses, and some caramel.  Flavor is the same with a decent bitter finish that lingers.  Im glad I picked this brew up today, much better then what I was expecting.
Pours a light brown color with a light brown head.  Aroma is of aged malts and brown sugar.  Roasty bitter flavor with some chocolate notes.
Poured a clear very dark ruby-brown color with a thin off-white head.  Nice smooth raosted aroma with some coffee notes.  Roasty flavor.  kind of on the dull side.  Semi-sweet.
Poured dark brown.. highly noticeable carbonation.. nice thick tan head.  Hints of unsweetened dark chocolate, coffee and is that caramel?  Very good beer.

Schwartzbiers always seem to come off on the thin side to me - or as it would probably be better said, Im so stupid I idnt know these were supposed to be this way. Very nice beer andas it was far more flavorful and complex (to me) than some of the more popular Germa ones Ive tried ....

Poured from a 16 ounce bottle into a pint glass, pitch black with a decent tan head. Aroma was very faint with a hint of coffee. Taste was suble with touches of roasted malt, coffee and baking chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel with some bitterness on the finish.

Bottle.  Last one out of a four pack, reserved specifically for rating.  

I allowed this lager to sit on the kitchen counter for roughly 10 minutes 

after opening to warm a bit before sampling.  When I say this is a big 

beer, Im not talking about big flavor or big aroma only.  The large, 

brown 16 oz. bottle that Sprecher Black Bavarian comes in allowed me to 

do the following: I poured two servings - one in a goblet so as to better 

capture the aromas, and one in a tall, flared pilsener glass. This has to 

be one of the best beers that comes packaged in a twist-top bottle. 

Appearance is dark brown, but has a burgundy-ish hue when held up to a 

lightbulb.  Head is a very light caramel color and mostly diminishing. 

Has a nice, sweet, inviting yeasty and vinous aroma, which must be one of 

the hallmarks of a schwarzbier.  The smell of chocolate malts are 

apparent also. Just enough hop bite to give it some character.  Texture 

is thickish, palate is extremely smooth and clean.  This dark offering 

from Sprecher goes down very easily.  I could drink these all afternoon, 

if the generous 5.8% ABV would let me.  The nice young lady with pigtails 

at The Keg Liquors in Clarksville IN must have spent 15 minutes trying to 

find a four pack of this for me in their walk-in cooler.  It was time 

well spent, as I have thoroughly enjoyed this dark lager.  Thanks to 

Sprecher for preserving the old ways and the traditional recipes.  Yummy.

One of my favorites from Sprecher. Sample was fifth brewed tried at Cellars LexLarp in St Paul. This is one of Sprechers oldest brand style of beer. Pours a near opaque dark brown witha a creamy tan head. Aromas has coffee, caramel and chocolate. Taste of toasted chocolate barley malt with some coffee. Roasted grain and coffee in the aftertaste. Very nice.

500cl - Aroma is roasted chocolate malts, caramel with some smoke creeping in.  Pours black with a small head and good lacing.  Flavor is very roasty dark malts, chocolate and crispy caramel.  Palate is sticky.  A nice tasty brew.
Lots of carbonation on this brownish black beer.  Carob nose with a mild coffee flavor.
This was a fantastic german style scharzbier.  It was a deep dark beer that had huge notes of coffee and choclate.  It was a fantastic effort.
Aroma, burnt wood, noble hops,  slighlty charcol (That comment reminds me of Old English 800).  Taste is smooth. Same taste I get when I eat burnt pizza crust (and I like that).

Bottle...thanks to sliffy...sorta. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of toasted malt, a bit of coffee perhaps. The flavor was light with toasted malt really comoing through. Of all the Sprechers, this one was the best thus far.

great beer had on tap and the happy Gnome. good stuff pours quite black nice thick tan head. hints of chocolate toffe cofe caramels etc. very smooth and blanced great stuff try one today oh and GET SURLY

An excellent beer, and even better on tap.  Just like everyone says, burnt caramel, coffee, roasted caramel...etc.  But why this beer stands out is that it is remarkably creamy.  
I was married in Wisconsin, and wanted a good local beer.  This was my choice.   
You can TASTE the Crastsmanship

Pours a dark brown with ruby tinged edges.  Nice chocolate, almonds, and smoke on the nose.  Flavor is outstanding, and shows off more of the toasted almonds, as well as some salted meat earthiness, and a great dark chocolate finish.  A great brew!
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: On tap @ hopleaf during the Monthlh Chicago Ratebeer Gathering.  Pours black with a beige head.  Flat aroma barely there.  Chocolate malt flavors a little bit burnt, with some pine hops.  Not bad overall, but it didnt seem like that great of a schwarz for being the best schwarz.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 Initial review, 3-13-07: Pint bottle. Aroma of hops, chocolate, coffee, and brussels sprouts. Its strong but not particularly enticing. The smell improves as one drinks. Pours a sparkling but otherwise largely opaque dark brown with an amber hue and a small amount of short-lasting tan head. The flavor features a heavily roasted coffee taste with a dash of dark chocolate and a hint of lemon. Delicious! Long, bitter, coffee-like aftertaste. Medium body. Lively in the palate. Sprecher Black Bavarian has the appetizing combination of the appearance and taste of a stout and the texture and mouthfeel of a lager. It also is in many ways surprisingly similar (but superior) to Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock.

Supplemental notes, 4-19-08: Roughly 4 oz. pour from a 16 oz. bottle, consumed at a beer tasting on 4-12-08. This bottle has been aged for over a year in my wine fridge. Crisp, malty aroma with a lemon scent. Pours dark brown with a red hue and beige head. Much sweeter taste than the younger version of the beer. Lemon zest. Coffee bitterness. Roasted, almost smoky, taste. Dry finish. Medium body.
Not sure what a Schwarzbier is, cause i thoutght this was a porter or stout or somthing, none the less, it was good stuff. Little bit o coffee, chocolate, smokey flavor. Had on tap at the happy gnome

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 16 oz bottle.  Pours a deep dark clearish brown, and a fizzy lingering head with some lace.  Aroma is nutty, dry toast, chocolate, and light sweet caramel and hints of herbal and tea-likehops.  Light roast and smokey flavors with roasted nuts, dark chocolate, bready, and a mineral-like finish.  Nice crisp and clean, but was almost a cross between a schwartz and dunkel.

16oz. bottle. Dark brown, almost black color with a small tan head. Light roasted malt aroma with some brown sugar and coffee notes. Flavor of roasted malts, pumpernickel bread, brown sugar and a mild sourness that bothered me somewhat. I had this beer a year or so ago and remembered liking it more than this. It wasnt bad by any means, just not as good as I thought.

A partially clear and hardly intimidating shade of black.  Straightforward roasted malt aroma.  Suggestions of rye and semi-sweet chocolate.  Caramel infused coffeecake, cola and maple wood on the tongue.  Not really endearing but nice enough, like an enjoyable but kind of unimaginative stout.
Ive been blessed to have had the privelige to taste her. Really probably the best beer ive ever tasted, but I am young.
Full bodied, malty brew that tastes clean on the palate. Refreshing for a dark lager.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 Black with good, foamy brown head / Sweet malt and molasses nose / Light to medium body with flavors of molasses, chocolate, and roast coffee  /  Body and crisp carbonation make this an easy all-season drinker / Crisp but not lingering finish.

Deep reddish colour with a light brown head. Malty, dark fruit sweet aroma with a light roasted note and vague hints of bread. Malty, caramel sweet flavor with notes of bread. Light dry and roasted finish with a fruity note.
Pours a nice black with nice tan head.  Joefflin had it right... very similar to GIs Oatmeal Stout.  Nice winter beer to warm you up.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2007 16 oz Pint bottle, poured into a pint glass. A very tasty brew.  Reminded me a lot of Goose Islands Oatmeal Stout.  Pours black, with no light shining through.  Its pretty much jet black, very appealing.  Nice tan head.  Aroma is coffe, caramel, and eggy.  The taste is nice and smooth, though i thought it was a tad watery for the style and it left a papery taste on the tip of my tongue.  Very enjoyable, and very good.

Bottle from Degarth. Interesting beer. Tastes like kind of an American take on a schwarz. Aroma is muddy molasses and eggplant, dry cane sugar and husky grain. Little complexity. Pours black with a nice head that fades, but is absolutely covered in tiny bubbles all along the side of the glass. Unsurprisingly, this is a bit fizzy and harsh in the mouth. A bit of pizza taste, really, with some unrefined sugars. Not my fave.
Black with slight brownish edge and Small, quick disappearing head. Mild coffee, chocolate, roasted malt ad tart. Nice smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle.  Malty aroma with light citrus overtones.  Dark black color with minimal head.  Flavor is dark malt, chocolaty, light coffee.  Balanced towards sweet with a light bitterness.  Slightly sour accents.  Mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation.  Very drinkable.  Good overall.
Bottled.  Poured black, black, black with a thin head.  Pleasing roasted malt aroma with hints of dark chocolate.  Rich.  Smooth mouth feel.  Not too heavy.  Very good beer.

Bottle shared by sliffy i think. Aroma of black licorice and chocolate with some maltiness. Flavor was a little bitter and a little off. Was just not my thing overall. Palate was a little weird feeling too. A little wheat coming through at the end.
Shared at Columbus tasting 5.  Anise aroma (whatd you say?) comes from a black body.  Medium palate.  Lots of roasted malts and coffee flavors--not too bad.
Shared at CTV5.Aroma was of slight chocolate.Pours black with a slight head.Got some slight chocolate in the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with a bitter finish.
Bottle: Brown with a tan head. Aroma of caramel, some fruits, and a bit of chocolate. Flavor, roasty, caramel, chocolate, some yeast. Not bad.

Poured an opaque black color with a medium sized tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roast, some caramel malts, and cocoa. Taste was roasty and chocolatey, with more caramel, and some smoked malts as well in the finish.
Nose is right on roast and a bit dusty.  Flavour is powerful chocolate with a thick malty quality that makes black lagers one of my favourite beers.
Black with small whispy head. Big malt and smokey roasted aroma. Flavor is smoked malts and a good amount of bitter chocolate.

Pours with a fluffy, initially three-finger thick, creamed chocolate to tan colored head that sits atop a simply black colored beer.  The aroma is full of roast malt notes; notes of burnt espresso beans, roasted grain husks, and even some notes of burnt toast towards the end dominate the aromatic profile.  This has a nice malty profile, yes it leans towards roasted grains, but there is also a nice, dry malt character here that, besides the roast profile, leans towards biscuit-like notes and toasted bread character.  Perhaps a touch of spicy hop aromas are here as well, but only just so.

The taste is medium full on the palate, and actually has quite a bit more body than I was expecting from the aroma.  In fact there is a solid malt sweetness here that really brings out a chocolate note that was not in the aroma.  The long finish leads a lingering note of burnt toast, bitter espresso and even some biting hop bitterness.  The finish really serves as a nice foil for the sweeter malt / chocolate notes that are noticeable in the fore-front.  There is enough roasted grain in this beer that it even has some roast derived acidity to it, it is not overly noticeable, but instead helps to balance some of the sweeter, rounder malt notes.  This certainly evokes thoughts of chocolate covered malt balls that have an espresso bean core (wouldnt that be a confection).

This is quite an enjoyable brew, and I am quite happy that it came in a 16oz package as it is the perfect beer to have more than twelve ounces of.  Perhaps a touch to hard with the acidity and bitterness in the finish, but enjoyable all the same.  Before I know it this beer is gone, so I must have liked it.

16 oz bottle, via Ofortuna.  Pours a very dark brown body under a dense creamy brown head that faded to a thin film.  Aroma is chocolaty and dry with a subtle fruitiness and nuttiness.  Very light chalkiness, coffee, and cocoa.  Flavor is balanced between chocolaty and nutty malt with some ale like qualities.  Finishes slightly sweet with a light hoppiness and some vanilla.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with fairly moderate soft carbonation.  Finishes with a soft creamy texture.  Overall, this was pretty nice.  Finally a Sprecher beer that Im not disappointed in, thats a first.

16 fl bottle. Black color with small tan head. Malty and roasted aroma with toffee and bitter chocolade. Good malty flavor with dry roastedness, coffee and toffee. Dry finish with bitter chocolade, coffee and fruity bitterness. Very balaced with excellent maltiness.
I love this beer.  Dark.  A lot going on in your mouth, rich.  Good aftertaste.  Caramel.  Hint of burnt sugar.

16 ounce bottle from ogglethorp; Bonus from my want list! Nose of faint coffee, yeast, and a little cocoa; opaque ebony with a medium tan head; Flavors (all light) of coffee, chocolate, mild hop bitterness, and caramel emanted from the medium body and the hops lasted into a weakly  bitter finish. I agrre it is a great Schwarzbier!

This Schwarzbier or dark Kulmbacher style lager is apparently not a style I care for. I like even light body stouts but this is too sweet, sour, bland for me. JUst too malt centric for my liking. Mouth feel was a turn off and lingering  aftertaste was off putting. The closest thing Ive tried that is similar is Capitals Munich Dark and I like that.
Thanks to my Secret Santa for this one.  Lots of Dark brown head on this black beer.  Aromas were faint, but roasty.  Flavors were better, with some coffee and chocolate.  Pretty good.

pours a lighter black with a one finger brown head. aroma is malt and a little hops, head does not last long though. flavor is a nice smooth malt with some hops and a little coffee. light to medium body with a little lacing. has some nice carbonation to smooth everything out. little sweet tasting and a little roastiness taste and aroma when it warms. very nice schwarzbier the best ranked and ONE of the best i ever had.
I dare someone to find a better version of this beer. If you do please let me know so that I may try some. My drink of choice but finding now that I relocated to So Cal has been difficult.

Dark color.  Smell of sugar, malt, chocolate, caramel, toffee, bread and smoke.  Tastes very sweet, with berries, roasted malt, rye, sugar cane, coffee and toffee.  Very interesting beer.  I will have more!

Big ol bottle.   Pours nearly black with a fairamont of tan colored head.   A little lacing.   Aroma is coffee, caramel, malt.   Flavor is coffee, malt, something spicy (rater before me noted rye) could be it, chocolate.   Palate is medium to full, smooth creamy, mildly carbonated, slightly bitter in the finish.  Great stuff.
Bottle. Dark red brown colour with a beige head. Light roasted, rye bread, corn aroma and taste. Medium body with a light sweet dry finish.

(Bottle 47 cl) Beautiful, clear mahogany with a tint of red and an off-white head. Lightly burned malt aroma. Medium body with sweetish and burned malt accents. A vague ashy edge and a malt bitter finish. 011206

Bottled. Reddish brown coloured. Beige/light brown dense head. Sweetness, cold coffee, caramel and some fruity notes in the aroma. Flavour of roast, coffee, sweetness and fruits. Medium to full bodied. Quite balanced and smooth. Ends on a roasted coffee note with some background alcoholnotes. Thanks to DavidP for this.
A deep red beer with a brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel, but also light notes of alcohol.
Bottled. Very dark reddish brown. Roasty bready aroma. Sweet malty and roasty flavour with light buttery notes. Dry roasty finish. Medium bodied. A pretty good Schwarzbier.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2007 Botle. Pours a dark brown color with a medium sized tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee beans with a hint of dark chocolate. Taste is watery and of burnt coffee with only a light malt presence. I was dissappointed in the lack of complexity and thought it was rather bland.

Just from the recommendation I knew that this was going to be a good one.  A little thicker, more oily than what Im used to with a Schwarzbier.  That, it turns out, is a good thing.  Robust, licorice-flavor really accents this one well.  Drinks remarkably easy.  Damn good.

12OZ bottle via degarth(thanks). Pours a near black with a small beige head. Nice aroma with notes of almonds, roasted coffee, and toffee. Taste is the same with some added plums, raisins, figs, hazlenuts, burnt malts. Some hops are evident in the finish. Very tastey beer.

What a great black lager...richly roasted coffee...maybe even a bitter espresso tinge, with chocolate, toffee, and smoky malts.  The alcohol is only noticable in the mildly dry finish.  These are really easy to drink back to back to back... Obvious black paten maltiness...Im hoping our homebrew using the same grain bill comes out a third as good as this baby!
Deep, dark black pour with a tan head.  Malt, toast, roast with a hint of coffee taste.  Nice dash of hops at the end, great beer!

bottle.  Aroma:  Coffee, anise, slightly sweet roasted malt, some light caramel.  Appearance:  Pours dark, dark brown with small chestnut highlights.  Head was light tan, small and short lived.  Flavor:  Roasted malt, coffee, caramel, light smoke, and some citrusy hops right before the finish.  Good, clean flavors.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Finish is semi dry.  Overall:  Great beer.  Great roasted malt flavors and a clean dry finish.

Bottle at Stockholm Beerfestival.
Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of malts, fruits and caramel.
Flavour of malts and caramel with roasted notes a´nd notes of spices and hops.

Wow, thanks to both MIBROmeo and Degarth for this loftily rated beer, which I am very glad to have a spare of!  The pour is jet black, with a half-finger tan head.  Aroma of huge roasty patent darkmalt, espresso, dark chocolate, some molasses.  Tastes roasty malty, with a big, chocolate syrupy and coffee flavor that stays on the dry side, plus some molasses, backdoor hops, and caramel hints.  The palate is complex, on the hefty side, and balanced well for this style.  The finish gets drier, and stays dense on the tongue, all the while maintaining the nice, complex dark malt/chocolate/coffe trifecta.

Bottled. Dark brown colour, not much head. Aroma is hops and quite hayish. Some hints of roasted malts with black chocolate. Flavour is quite the same, but the roasted malts come in the strongest. The aftertaste is citrus fruity and also roasted malts. Wellbalanced.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 30 Sep) Pitch black colour with brown, disappearing, head. Malty nose with soft notes of chocolate and coffee with milk. Roasted taste with chocolate, hints of smoke and well balanced notes of citrussy hops in the finish. Rather dry, medium body. Very good and balanced, but wouldnt suffer from some more punch.

Bottled.
Very dark brown, not much head. Burnt malts, brown sugars in the nose. Malty, roasted malty with burnt sugars. Toasted/burnt aftertaste. Balanced profile.

(Stockholm Beer Festival 2006) Black, brown head. Malty aroma, almost a bit vinous, roasted, vanilla and cocoa. Hoppy, roasted flavor with cocoa, licorice and tar notes. Very good, I really liked this beer.

[Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival]  Very dark brown, small head. Roasty coffee aroma. Light bodied with  clean mouthfeel. Centered around the roasty malt, its fragile intriguing malt flavours are really something extra. The hard mouthfeel distracts, and prevents it from becoming world class.

16 oz. bottle via 1FastSTi - Been looking forward to this beer for awhile - Pours a clear brown color with a light tan head.  Has a light roasted and caramel malt aroma.  Light roasted malt flavor.  A very smooth medium to full body beer.  Very nice beer.  Thanks Blake.
16 Oz bottle.  Dark color, with a nice head and nice lacing.  Taste is wheat, with lots of coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is fairly light.  A very good beer.

Bottle. Poured black color with a large frothy brown head that lasted with good lacing. Moderate caramel and coffee aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium roasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer both in total and style.

What a great looking beer!  Dark, almost black, with a great brown head it screams "you are in for a treat!"  First taste is almost all roastiness.  There is a lot of malt but very little sweetness.  The aroma is subdued but is roastiness.  Once in a while a hint of sweetness comes through in the malt but then a tartness comes right behind it.  As the beer warms the malts come to the front more and bring some toffee.  Also, there is some bitterness but nothing but smoothness in the aftertaste.  This beer is top shelf.

Love this one. I have had Sprecher that I have left or dumped but this is exceptional. Strong but not over powering. nice combination of coffee, carmel and chocolate with a strong but pleasent after taste that hung in there. very much a great call during a poor performance on a Sunday afternoon watching the Packers stumble through a game.

Bottle.  I was skeptical at first, but no more: one of the best lagers Ive ever had, uncompromisingly dark and dry.  Pitch black pour wih no ruby shining through, dark brown head (and legs!).  Aroma of sweet malt, thick and rich, grain, very subtle funk, stronger notes of dark bread (Schwarzbrot) and molasses, and a light hint at fruitiness.  Taste is very dark, strong roast ... dark bread ... brute strength!  Schwarzbrot, molasses, undercurrent of caramel.  Full-bodied without a trace of syrup.  Not too complex, but strongly bitter and flavorful.  Very crisp and solid mouthfeel, extremely dry ... prison-dry.  Smooth swishing, but still a lager.  Lovely long aftertaste.  Overall, a powerhouse, a butt-kicker, aggressive ... but rounded and highly enjoyable.  Superb (and paired well with pumpkin pie)!

Thanks to someone who I traded with for this. LOL. Really though? This is the best one? I thought it was very good but I cant believe its the highest rated. Black pour, fairly large head with good lacing and decent head retention. Aroma is soft milk chocolate, caramel, light on coffee and roast. Smooth and creamy milky body. Really good, I hope I can find a better one though.

Pours very dark, much like a stout, with a quickly dissipating brown head. Aroma is of burnt malts and coffee. The flavor is burnt malt with a coffee influence. There are supporting flavor notes coming from a bit of molasses sweetness and dark chocolate. This beer is light in carbonation and light in body. Might even be a bit on the watery side. Nice taste, good beer.
Dark brown color with tan head. Aroma smells musky with hnts of nut. Flavor is lightly nutty with slightly bitter aftertaste.

16 oz bottle.  Dark chocolate brown with a thin walnut head.  Malty nose with undertones of coffee.  Tangy and stoutish with espresso and residual mocha.  Medium body dissipates quickly and finishes clean.

New in town. Aroma is sweet malts with a metallic twinge and extremely faint smokey and chocolate hints. Body is dark brown approaching full black and sports a rapidly diminishing  tan head. Coffee, chocolate, dark roasted malts. Has an almost porter like flavor at first, but with a lighter mouthfeel. Slight hints of molasses through the middle with a bitter lingering finish. At times it has porter and dunkel flavors, but never truly gets all that schwarzbier-y. Still decently tasty.
Its pretty black.  Thin head, with a roasted nut aroma.  Slight metallic like flavor.  Some choclate malt under tones.  This is a refreshing brew.  Quite solid, I must say.

Black with a thick brown head.
Sweet roasty malt and coffee aroma.
Flavor is sweet and rich with a roasty sweet chocolate finish.
Bottle. Decent malt and spicey aromas. Black body with decent tan head. Body was watered down and had slight sweetness and bitter flavor. Left a bitter and coffee aftertaste on palate.

Bottle thanks to Kevin. Coffee and citrus in the aroma. Almost black with light edges and a café au lait colored head. Roasty flavor with chocolate and more coffee. Nice mf. It does not have the metallic notes often found in schwarzbier, which is really nice. Very roasty for a schwarzbier and quite strong. I would probably have categorized this as a dry stout if I had not known what it was.

Pours ruby black into a shaker.  Brown conglomerate head slowly recedes leaving no lacing.  Prune, fig,  and caramel malt notes.  Upfront chocolate and dried fruit with an thin, sweet, smokey lasting finish.

Attractive deep mahogany/brown pour with a creamy head that is nearly tan in color. Musty aroma with prune and chocolate amidst roasted (almost smoky) notes. Smooth, fat mouthfeel with a dry finish. Chocolate flavor dominates... kind of like Kayo with a touch of dark fruit and some coffee bitters to finish. This started out reminding me of a kit stout but gained complexity (and started holding my interest) as it opened up.
