UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 11/05 Hopleaf-10.5oz pour. Dark color, looks black in the lowly lit room, with a light khaki head. Aroma is dark roasted malt and coffee. The initial mouthfeel is large and it finishes the same. Initial taste is coffee, caramel, and bittersweet milk chocolate. There is a milky, creamy flavor present. Very enjoyable. Incredible depth of flavor.

Looks great, like a real stout. Not much aroma. The flavor is not like a lager at all really; more like a dunkel although a little thin in parts. I guess this combo makes a schwarzbier. The best beer in the 8pack of 4 styles by far. Very nice.

Draught at Old Capitol Brew Works. Dark, dark brown, almost opaque. Red around the edges. Thin tan head with minimal lace. Aroma is brown sugar, light molasses, and raisins. Creamy, malty milk chocolate flavor with a light roasty finish. Pretty solid for a schwarzbier.

Bottle courtesy hezron.  Aroma has some java coffee, clean mountain air.  black brown underbelly beer, small light brown head.  Tastes of chocohops, some twigs and leaves.  smooth, a little light bodied.  Becomes a little bitter with buildup.
UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 This is by far the best sprecher beer.   A strong taste in coffee and chocolate.  I would strongly reccomend this one!

nice brew...black pour with small brown head...aroma is similar to an impy/baltic porter (nice sweet caramels, molasses, coffee, chocolate, and cream)...flavor is much more roasted than sweet in character, and is very porter-like...great chocolate finish...nice palate

Very complex beer, not to be taken lightly.  Aroma was roasted malts and bread.  Mouthfeel was heavy, contributing to a long finish.  Flavor is malty and bittersweet.  What many raters are taking as chocolate and roasty coffee, I took a little differently.  The flavor is somewhat reminiscent of the aroma of dew and wet earth, particularly if youve had the experience while camping.  I know, thats a strange comparison, but seriously.  The finish is long, as I said, with a nice burnt toast character.  Good beer, if a bit too complex to be a casual beverage.

This stuff is black, just like Ving Rhames. Slight off white head. Nose is rather subdues compared to the flavor. Smells of roast, yeast, and maybe a bit of chocolate. Flavor is semisweet chocolate, and lots of oily roast. Tons of coffee in this one as well. Good mix of bitter and sweet. Yum yum. Man do I love me some dark German (or in this case, German style) lagers.

16oz bottle, no date.  Pours a black with a medium brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, molasses, coffee.  Aroma wasnt too strong, then I decided to get smart and let it warm up.  Flavor is very sweet and caramelly, some bitterness from the roasted malts.  Even though this is my first Schwarzbier (rating), nothing was really surprising.  Very good beer either way though.  Creamy mouthfeel, light carbonation.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Dark and roasty, with strong coffee and cocoa flavors. Has strong malts for dark roasted meats. Enjoy on a cool night

16 oz. bottle.  Pours out a deep, dark chocolate brown with a thin, quickly disappating tan head.  The aroma is full of rich, roasted malt with chocolate, caramel and dark roast coffee.  It tastes even better than  it smells, a wonderful blend of toasted malt, burnt caramel, and milk chocolate with hints of coffee and anise.  The palate is complex though just a tad thin, but with the taste you keep thinking it has to be thick like a stout or porter.  Far and away the best schwarzbier Ive ever had, and one of my favorite beers of all time - great to have as number 100 for me.  Im thrilled I can actually buy this in Florida now.

A black beer with a large tan head.  The aroma is not super strong, but still very nice- malty chocolate, caramel, and sweet.  The flavour is roasty, some sort of sour flavour, caramel, and also sweet (almost a fruity sweetness, but I cant quite pinpoint the fruits).  Its smooth and approaching creamy (maybe just a little watery).  I liked it!

Pours black to brwon with a hardy, though slightly ephemeral head.  Big sweet chocolate and caramel malt in the nose with a fair amount of creaminess.  This brew feels really nice in the mouth, foaming up nicely and just feeling really smooth.  The malt is even huger on the tastebuds.  Sweet caramel, bittersweet chocolate, a hint of coffee and something downright spicey.  The finish is coffee with a little acid.  Quite different from the only other schwarzbier Ive had (Sam Adams, eck), but in a really good way.  This seems to remind me almost more of a baltic porter, though certainly smoother.  This is certainly my favorite lager to date.

The aroma is full of heavily toasted malts, a tiny bit of chcolate, and an even smaller amount of coffee. It is also slightly smokey. The appearance is dark red-brown with a medium tan head. The flavor is sweet and acidic with a smatering of chocolate, coffee, burnt malt, caramel and bitterness. The palate is average but the beer is good.

While pouring the beer into the glass it looks like liquid chocolate - in the glass it looks like oil with a nice brown head.  The aroma is like toasted chocolate that is rich and inviting.  Medium bodied beer with adequate carbonation that is a bit sprintzy, but it still seems to take the flavors through the mouth.  Taste is chocolate and malty with rich caramel.  The finish is lightly bitter hops.  Further down the glass the carbonation calms down and the beer takes a velvety character.  A wonderful beer that would be a perfect dessert.

Black. Small, foamy, tan head. Aroma of roasty, burnt chocolate and caramel, smoke, and just a touch of some banana and clove. Same flavors. Rich, roasty, smooth, easy drinking, medium body. 100 style percentage sounds about right.

Pours thick, velvety and foamy with a beautiful light brown head, mostly lasting. Its color is a very dark and opaque like a night in Bavarias Black Forest. Its aroma is of chocolate and carmel. Very creamy on the palate, with a malty taste, not bitter. Its finish is clean, crisp, slightly dry with a hint of coffee that is very pleasing. This robust beer can stand up to any meal and works well with brats, burgers, steaks or with peanuts or pretzels. Delightful.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2007 16oz bottle courtesy of Kevin. Thanks again! Pours dark brown, almost black with a nice diminishing tan head. Nice aroma of dark roasted malt, cocoa powder, and coffee. Texture is slightly watery with light carbonation. Flavor is dominated by mild roast coffee, with some peppery notes. Finish is dry, bitter, and slightly acidic. Overall, pretty darn good

16 oz. bottle from BevMo.  Pours dark brown - almost black - with brick highlights when held to light and a large creamy beige head.  Roasty malt aroma, bitter chocolate and molasses, bitter herbs, bit of sour milk and cream.  Sweet roasty malt flavors as well, coffee, coacoa, brown rice, mild vegetabley herbs, lactose and hints of pepper in the finish.  Medium body and creamy carbonation.  Surprisingly good based on my experience with other Sprecher beers and quite enjoyable overall.

(bottle - 1 pt) Dark yet clear ruby pour with not much foam on top. Aroma is malty and kind of spicy with hints of port, coffee and caramel. The flavor is rather sweet and dry at the start. The middle has a nice coffee flavor mixed with a nice malt balance and a slightly dry and bitter finish. Lots of flavors all throughout.

Black, or at least dark brown, with a thin, off-white head. Spicy, creamy aroma, with  a hint of coffee. Dusty and dry, with a strong coffee and pepper flavor. Maybe some rye, too. Surprisngly bitter, hoppy finish. Nice, very flavorful.

Bottle (small sample) at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 01/10/2005
Dark coloured and smooth on the palate. Slightly dry malt and roast flavoured finish.

Bottle (500ml).  via trade with Ughsmash.  Poured deep ruby-brown with an average foamy-creamy-sticky lasting tan head.  Mild, subtle, appealing roast, hop and lightly fruity aroma, dry and toasty.  Taste is dark molasses-sweet, with coffee, chocolate, yeast, roast malt, prune, raisin and plum fruitiness, detectable hops too - nice balance of bitter and sweet.  Mouthfeel is only lightly carbonated, a little watery, and mildly acidic - really, this is an excellent schwarzbier, the roastiness intensifies as it warms - Id have it again in a shot - thanks for this one, Ughsmash!
Just a damn good brew.  The head pours nice and frothy.  You get the aromas, the full taste, and a nice, clean finish.

bottle. deep black with a small tanned ring of head. the aroma is fairly quiet and subtle - some wheat, toast malt, and mild dark fruits. mild bitter roast flavour with some sticky sweetness and dark fruit notes. not bad, though not particularly interesting IMO. Thanks for sharing, Len.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2006 Glad Im getting to try this one, thanks so much Phil, you da man! Opens with a dark, almost opaque pour, sporting a thin, slightly watered mocha head of medium sized bubbles. Mild roasty aromas, light coffee bean, molasses, and milk chocolate. Flavours are much of the same. Roasty, chocolate, with a mild fruity sweetness. Smooth finish, lingering fruit and coffee flavours. A good session schwarz, if there is one. Thanks so much Phil! As a side note, I have heard that if you put some spring water in this one, it will bring it down to about 4% ABV, and it will then seem like a mild stout. Ill have to try it.

Thanks to SpringLicker for this one.  Dark walnut pour, clear with a thick lingering head.  Sweet burnt caramel and roasted malts in the aroma, as well as hints of black pat molasses.  Roasted malt taste and decent carbonation.  Nothing to be overly excited about, but this rather dull taste leads to a wonderful lingering finish with dark chocolate, roasted malt, & light hops with a metallic hint.  Medium body with a slick/sticky mouth feel.  This one just did not do it for me as much as other schwarzbier.  I wonder if I just wasnt in the mood...Perhaps Ill try it again one day.

(02.16.06) 16 oz brown bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL.  Black ruby hued lager having a small tan head.  Soft carbonation. Corn/nutty aroma.  Full bodied lager that starts with light malt sweetness and dried prune/roasted malt flavors.  Finishes dry with roasted malt/ bitterness fade.  Full of roast malt flavors and intensely flavorful.  Smooth, creamy, and immense beer.  Delicious.

16 oz bottle. Black color, thick tan head. Aroma of malt with a hint of coffee. This beer has a lot of body; bittersweet taste that finishes off smooth. A full bodied  interpretation of a Schwarzbier.

Black Bavarian is a schwarzbier or "black beer" by style, and is one of the finest examples I have ever had the pleasure to taste. This style of beer originated in Eastern Germany, and it is a darker, roastier version of Munich Dunkles. This beer is just packed with lots of flavor, and being a lager, it is just so drinkable. 

Sprecher Black Bavarian pours to an ebony color with a thick, tan, bubbly head, and a good bit of carbonation. When held to the light, this beer is really a beautiful dark ruby color. The nose on this beer is a joy. Aromas of roasted malt, sweet malt, and a touch of smoke flood the nose. The palate is just packed with malt flavors, lots of good sweet malt, a bit of roast, and a touch of coffee. This is a lager, so the body is very smooth and round. Black Bavarian finishes with a long, dry, roasty, finish that slightly lingers. 

Without a doubt, this beer is one of the best I have ever tasted, and an all time favorite of mine. This beer goes great with German fare of course. I have matched it with grilled bratwurst, or grilled chicken. It also works very well with barbecue. Seek this beer out if you can find it, it is one of the few domestic examples of schwarzbier, and in my opinion, the best example on the market today.

Pours dark brown almost black with thin tan head. The aroma of this beer is very distinct with noticable hints of vanilla, malts and caramel ( kind of reminded me of A&W cream soda ). The flavor of this beer has hints of caramel, coffee, malts, and vanilla and is extremely well balanced with a very smooth and creamy palate. An OUTSTANDING beer !!

Deep black color, like staring into my empty soul.  Virtually no head (just a thin ring on the sides).  Has a mild roasty coffee aroma.  Pleasant roasty flavor.  Body is decent, with a decent amount of carbonation.  Overall, this is a nice beer, and I would enjoy it again.

In the bottle at Bill B.s birthday party. Black colored beer with a weak watery head. Makes up for appearance with its delicious rich flavor. Outstanding roasted flavor and aroma. Has a nice mild tartness and well-balanced hops. Has a molasses sweetness that lingers beyond the last sip.
Aroma of malt and coffee. Body is thin and has an earthy too dry finsh. Tastes like cold coffee with a hint of malts. Blah!

(16 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!) Back in February of 1999, I threw a big "1000th Beer Party" complete with t-shirts.  That night, I rated my 1000th beer, and it was Sprecher Black Bavarian.  Nearly seven years have passed, and Im well over 3100 now.  But this was an awesome beer to celebrate on that historic evening, and I still really love this beer.  Malty, very roasty, and moderately bitter, this beer also presents a light sourness, but also a hops flavor I can actually taste, some light spices, very tasty chocolate and molasses, and a moderate smokiness.  Overall, superb balance and a real nice complexity here.  Aromas are more basic: roast, chocolate, molasses, spice, light smoke.  Medium-full bodied with lively carbonation on the palate, and a greater variety of intriguing flavors to spice up the mouthfeel.  Very dark brown, ruddy highlights at the edges, but nearly black through the center.  The light tan head barely rises to a quarter inch in height, and then settles to a ring, leaving no lacing on the glass.  Even after all these ratings, its still one of the best dark lagers Ive ever tasted.  I really wish this saw some west coast distribution, Id be a regular customer.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2006 Bottle.  Strong molasses aroma.  Black-brown color with little head.  Strong molasses malt.  Has more of a stout flavor than a schwarzbier.

Bottle - big complex dark malt nose.  Black as the name implies with a beige head the is smallish, but creamy and has good retention.  A delicious brew.  Chocolatey and roasty with a touch of coffee.  A very soft and creamy mouthfeel.  I really like this one alot and would love to have some on draft!

16 oz. bottle.  Poured a clear deep mahogany with a well-retained toffee head.  Full, malty aroma of roasted cocoa and slightly burnt coffee... powerful yet delicate.. really enticing.  Bakers chocolate first in the flavor, with heavily roasted coffee right behind.  Hints of vanilla and caramel around the edges and at the finish.  Extra smooth mouthfeel with an ideal low-medium level of carbonation.  Left some memorable roasty chocolate and coffee on the finish, with just a touch of coffee bitterness.  Remarkably tasty brew!

On tap at The Village Tap.  Pours almost black... thats shocking!  A thin caramel colored head skimmed the top of this until completely melting away.  Plenty of charcoal with hints of cocoa and light spices.  Lightly hopped.  An enjoyable beer.

Really love the BB.  A favorite around our house, chocolately and rich, yet with a delicate nose and robust flavor.  
A MUST for Stout lovers.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2006 Clear brown black pour, with a foamy head of tan. Wicking creamy malt aroma with caramel and a hint of Irish Whiskey. Slightly estery malt. A good run of those ubiquitous european hops. Fairly well balanced, but for me, overall unimpressive. Solid, german beer. RERATE. I had this again and enjoyed the coffe and roasted oak notes, but found the hop notes subdued and missing. There were some sour fringes and metallic bites that left me a little unbalanced. However, the lagery smoothness combined with the dark malt, make it a respectable Schwarz for sure.

The aroma is of strong roasted malt and persistent.  The color is a deep black with a creamy tan head.  The flavor is a complex mixture of roasted and chocolate malt.  Black Bavarians aftertaste is smooth and complex.

Light tasting schwarzbier with little head retention and a non-existent finish.  Hops make a statement in the body but the specialty malts used are weak.  This is definately a lager with a crisp aftertaste, but in the end falls short of expectations.
Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells lightly of grapes in addition to chocolate ans spice.  Taste is slightly bitter with some nice toffee notes.

Bottle compliments of MrFacto Dark brown color, moderate carbonation and little to no head and lacing. The nose is toasty with roasted malt, no fruitiness nor alcohol, rich malts. The flavor is rich and malty, doughy/toasty with a touch of hops and a bit of vanilla flavors. Some chocolate and other mild roasts are present. Like a black pilsner, very rich and chewy but easy drinking with roasted anecdotes. Thanks Matt!
Bottle. Deep brown in color with a nice head.  Rich chocolate aroma.  Malty and roasty flavor. Well balanced. Rich tasting. Smooth. Nice beer. Drinkable.
Coffee brown with very little light. Aroma is rich chocolate malts and toffee. Taste is beuatifully balanced between the sweet grains, chocolate and hops. Tasty.
Pours a dark brownish/black with small tan head.Nice Chocolate/coffee aroma.Upon first sip,had a VERY balanced Mouthfeel with coffee roast flavors coming through!Very Good!
(16oz bottle) Small tan head atop a red-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel, some roasty.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel, light roasty.  Smooth medium body.

Pours black with a huge tan head that slowly fades. Aroma of dark roast, and some bittersweet chocolate. Flavor of chocolate nibs, some coffee, caramel, and a slight licorice the fits in between the main flavors. Light body, silky palate made frothy buy the head. Extremely drinkable for such a huge delicious roast malt profile. If homemade hot cocoa was turned into beer this would be it.

On tap at brewery and Stamm House in MIddleton, and now at home in the bottle.   Pours a fine brown head with good retention.  Deep amber-brown.  Aroma of nuts and coffee.  Flavor starts big with roasted malt then chocolate and well done beefsteak.  Fine tobacco. Ashes.  Short on palate at first then long roasted nuts in the finish.  Fantastic.

Wow!  This was a surprise.  I saw it was a lager and thought - well, maybe it will be ok because its "Black Bavarian Style" whatever that means.  Whatever they do with this - they do it right.  Its no stout - but certainly is no lager!  Pourse dark, dark brown with a two finger tan head.  Light on the aroma, but great malty taste hits you right from the beginning with chocolate tones.  A medium mouthfeel with the carbonation you would expect in a lager, but some of the weight you would expect from a stout.  Finishes with a bit of hoppiness.  Very enjoyable.

Another bottle thanks to my S.S..  Pour is nice and simple black with a light foam top.  Aroma is light in roasted coffee and malt, also has some more earthy notes of pete and fresh dirt.  Flavor is creamy and rich, some tones of chocolate, malt, wheat, cream.  All blending quite good with a mouthfeel that is crisp and somewhat dry, adding to a coffee flavor towards the end.
Black as midnight body with tiny head.  Rich and delightful.  Chocolate is the dominating tone.

16oz bottle pours black with a creamy tan head.  Looks almost stout-like in  the glass.  Aroma is light chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor is quite chocolatey sweet with some caramel and roasted malt flavor.  A nice smoky chocolate finish makes you come back quickly for another sip.  On the palate this is quite smooth and thick for a schwarzbier.  Seems much like a porter.  Reguardless of what it is labeled it is a nice brew.  I enjoyed this one.

Ill tell you what this is a really sweet and full flavored beer. but once the taste hits you palate its not going anywhere.  its really good but lacks some sophistication that could make it awesome
Black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of cocoa and roasted malt.  Thick, with an initial hops flavor followed by lots of roasted malt and coffee.  Deep, smoky finish.  Delicious.

Pours a black color with thin tan head that quickly fades away.  Smells of faint chocolate and I couldnt pick up much else aside from a bit of malt.  Taste is awesome!   First taste on the tongue is a bit of floral helps that soon fade and give way to the chocolate, roasted coffee, and caramel which do not make an appearance until the finish.  Very smooth and delicious!!!
Yep, its black alright.  It also has a huge air-filled head and a sweet malt aroma.  This is a bit thin, but gives an OK roasty start, followed by a sharp predominate sweetness.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2005 Pour is black with a nice creamy head.  Aroma and flavor is of sweet chocolate. glides smoothly over the tongue. Rich and creamy.  I knew it was going to be good, but this was very good.

Bottle courtesy of qdog. Pours dark brown with no head. This smells like a Ricola (original) cough drop to me, which is a good thing. Flavor had some syruppy molasses and lots of dark roasted grains. Decent.
Pours an opaque black with a thin tan head.  Aroma and taste is of chocolate malt.  Mouthfeel is medium.  Very nice black beer.

Nice, thick light brown head of very fine bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Head lasts for a while.  Wonderful aroma with milk, chocolate, roasted grains and a bit of soy sauce.  Color is a very dark port red/black.  Roasted grains, plenty of malts, bitterswet chocolate and a bit of coffee round a very full and creamy flavor.  Finish is slightly bitter with more coffee.  An excellent schwarzbier.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 Aroma is full of cookie, toasted, nutty, roasted malts, milk chocolate, molasses and caramel.  Light flowers and cinnamon.  Appearance is a fully lasting large creamy light brown head with excellent lacing.  The body is clear and a dark brown/black color.  The flavor is moderately/heavy sweet with a light bitterness.  The finish is long.  Roasted milk chocolate, sweet caramel, and brown sugar note the flavor.  The palate is full and mostly creamy, although, theres a watery aspect to it too.  The carbonation is lively.  Very aromatic, very fulfilling.

Bottle from qdog.  Nice deep brown color with some red when backlit.  Small off-white head.  Rich molasses aroma.  Medium bodied and smooth.  A little bit of licorice and molasses in flavor.  Decent black beer.

big malty nose a light grass hop scent dark in color w/ a frothy head.  Creamy smooth palate nicely carbonated.   a bitter hop front milder as it warmed bringing out a sweet carmel/molasses malt flavor.

Bottle:  Very malty and sweet aroma.  Lots of molasses, toffee, light chocolate, and light nuttiness.  Pours a dark brown with red hilights.  Real light molasses and toffee up front with some nuttiness added in the finish.  Thanks to qdog.

Dark brown body, small creamy tan head. Nice raisin nut bran and coffee in nose. Pretty good sized flavor...  earthy and roasted malt, dry roasted coffee finish. Pretty good overall... balanced and nothing wrong.

Bottle, color is dark brown/black with red tones, nice thick off white head, nice lacing, aroma of earth, roasted grains, chocolate and toffee, nice taste of chocolate, toffee, and a hint of hops and chocolate at the end.

bonus brew in my last trade.pours a dark brown color with a light brown head.smells like earthy malts,and a bit of hops.nice smooth mix of caramel malts,earth,and hops.very well balanced and easy drinking.
Pour is a deep black with a small  tan head.  Aroma is roasty and malty.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee and caramel with a touch of hops thrown in there.  Very nice and satisfying.

Very dark and thick-looking, with a hint of red on the sides of the glass and a nice coffee-tinted head.  Aroma is cloves, roasted malts, with a hint of chocolate.  Taste is nicely roasty, coffee, chocolate, cloves, and spices.  Was not as "full" as it looked, but I expected this.  Nice hoppy coffee bitterness afterwards, with a touch of chocolate and licorice.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2005 Not much light got through this one and it had a durable one finger head and light lacing. Nice chocolatey coffee aroma with a spicy hop note. Robust dark malt roasty flavor with some chocolate and caramel and a well blended bitterness-smooth finish-one of the best dark lagers Ive ever drank.

pour was amazingly dark, i have seen some stouts that werent this dark and full looking.aroma was malty and chocolate laden...the coffee and caramel didnt really come through.  flavor was interesting..none of the flavors dominated, but they all seemingly took turns, coffee first, caramel lightly in the middle, chocolate late, with just a tad bitterness on the tail end.  a very rich mouthfeel and full body, an almost velvety feel.  this was an interesting beer at least, a very enjoyable one at best...im leaning far to the best side.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2005 A rich, dark flavor.  Has a good, moderate thickness.  Not quite full-on coffee, not quite bitter...not quite anything really.  This really isnt comparable to any other style of beer.  It tastes like the word "toasted".  There you go, toasted.

The beer pours black, with a tan head.  Great roasted coffee and malts, improved vastly by the fact that they dont weigh down the palate.  Its a suprisingly drinkable, strongly roasted beer.  A pleasure.

Nice coffee, malt aroma.  Strong coffee flavor with a very good smoothness in the malt.  There is a medium bitterness at the end because of the coffee. A touch on the sweet side to.   Overall very good flavored beer just no complexity.

Had this on tap.  The head pulls a magic trick, one second it is there, and the other it is gone.  Nice and dark.  Tastes of chocolate and coffee.  A little thin as far as the body goes, but a good beverage all the same.

Deep garnet in color; medium head. Lots of roasted malt. Coffee notes dominate. Tiiny bit of tartness in the sides of the mouth. Subtracted a few points in overall because I met the owner one time and he was a complete asshole.
Had this on draught in Milwaukee.  Thin, orange head, nose of chocolate and smoke, taste of caramel and malt.  This one was good.

Best way to describe this brew is a lager version of Porter.  Much the same familiarities of a Porter: chocolate malt taste and similar aroma and mouthfeel -- at least initially.  After the swallow you detect the lager characteristics such as the clean, crisp aftertaste and hop bitterness with none of the Porter mouth-coating feel.  Overall a very good brew; something Ive come to expect from Sprecher.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005 Coffee colored, light head. Chocolate and malt flavors everywhere. Very creamy and sweet but just enough dryness to keep it from being too syrupy. Coffee with sugar flavors. Wouldnt mind drinking this anytime. And four 16oz bottles..perfect.
Very dark, with little head. Chocolaty, but not too much so, still has a bite to it, Nice flavor, very nice, smooth.. good drinking... Cant wait to have again!
Pours black with a large light tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and minerals...  Flavor of dark malted barley and chocolate.  Sweet and malty.  The palate is creamy.

oh Thanx to my Main Man Duane! He knows what I like. Poured almost black, with a fizzy tan Huge head.  Ahhh, the aroma of coffee and chocolate roasted malts. This huge and complex aroma has me searching.... There are some elements I cant place. (my wife is looking at me as I press my nose near the glass). The aroma is more than pleasant. The first taste ii s like a chocolate milk with coffee. I am loving this. The carbonation is low which leads to an excellent drinkability.  There is a creaminess to this that takes the flavor to a level of enjoyment I cant quite put into words. The finish is smooth like a babys butt, and the coffee + chocolate flavors settle into the nose long after the drink is gone.  This is a great brew. Thanx again Duane. You, you are a good one pal.
UPDATED: SEP 30, 2007 (Bottle)   Pours a dark brown body with a small creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, and chocolate.  Slight bitter finish.  Roasted malt flavor.

Bottle. Poured a medium sized tan head that mostly diminished, good lacing, fine-large sized bubbles, carbonated, and a reddish brown hue. Aroma was malty, caramel, coffee, and roasty. The flavor was malty, chocolate, some caramel, coffee, burnt, roasty, and smokey tasting. Tingly, dry mouthfeel. Medium body.

01.19.05  Thanks to doubletriple for the trade!  Very close to black in color with amber highlights and a large tan head.  Aroma is bready, roasty, and mineral.  Soft palate carries bright flavors all around while getting even softer with temp.  Loads of roast; nice lagery yeast character that never gets to the heavy point that I really dont like in many lagers.  Exceedingly drinkable.  Underlying dry cocoa powder flavors and crisp finish emerge and linger even as the beer approaches room temp.  VERY nice stuff, thanks George!

UPDATED: APR 11, 2007 2004 bottle from Heemer77, thanks!  Stupendously thick, rich, dark pour.  Looks almost like a nitrogen tap.  Viscous, creamy and has a perfectly formed, long-lasting oatmeal colored head.  Unfortunately, it seems to be rather filtered.  Smells of light milk chocolate, sweet toffee, anise, hints of oily roast and some slight yeastiness.  A dried out, dusty, almost ash-like note on the end of the nose, as well.  Flavor begins with a balanced mix of sweet and dry.  Youve got more oily roast as noted from the nose, mixing with a medium sweet caramel/toffee-like flavor.  Brown sugar, tons of creamy milky chocolate and then the coffee.  Its like a cup of dunkin donuts coffee, with a packet of sugar and some milk in it.  Slightly watery, not terribly challenging, but still pretty good.  Finishes with more brown sugar/brown malt appeal.  A touch on the sweet side overall, but the lager element serves to keep the beer from getting very heavy and adds a touch of crisp yeastiness on the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2005 Very dark, nice puffy, creamy head.  Big nose, some chocolate there, light roast, some caramel sweet.  Great flavor, light cocoa, very sweet, toasty and roasty.  Love the finish on this one, mildly smoky and it hangs around in the mouth for a very long time.  Good body, just heavy enough to give it some heft.  Very impressive stuff.

Gorgeous pour. Dark brown, pretty much opaque with a medium, creamy light tan head. Glass lacing is above average. The aroma is huge and malty. Sweet, toasty, light coffee, and bitter chocolate. The flavor is real treat, toasty sweetness up front, then a good deal of bitterness develops. Chocolate and acidity come in late. Very nice. Body is medium, finsih is medium acidic and bitter. All around a real winner and far away the best schwarzbier I have had.

Bottle Pours a black with dark brown edges, a nice light tan head and seriously lasting lacing.  Aromas are of dark roast malts coffee and chocolate.  Flavors are much the same.  Chocolate than coffee.  Notes of black leather, (dont ask me how I know what black leather tastes like) and some smokey hitts as well Swwet enough that it is not too bitter and quite drinkable.  Feel is very smooth.  Slick even.  After tastes lacks any unpleasant bitterness.  All around a great "Black Beer"
Black, with a tan head. Aromas of malt and chocolate. Body is on the heavy side, with coffee, chocolate, malt, and a little smoke. Mouthfeel is creamy and pleasant.

Flavor is truely a consolodation of chocolate, then coffee, and finally caramel (in that order). The problem with that is it has a little too much coffee taste for my liking.  I like coffee, but not cold! The aroma and texture are wonderful. This swirls in the mouth almost like an ice cream drink, and slithers down the throat like the root beer from a float. After taste is smooth and creamy. 
I like this brew. If the coffee flavor were toned down, just a bit, Id like it more!

I want a glass like in the picture. Well anyway this one was a dark brown color. The aroma is full of chocolate and some caramel. The flavor was pretty sweet with a bit of dark fruit, licorice, and chocolate. The body was medium on this. I certainly enjoyed it. My what a nice haul of beer Facto sent to the beer deprived Southern U S of A.

Worty aroma is sweet with a light smokiness and some herbal vegetal character. Opaque, dark brown with thin tan head that recedes to ring. Up front sweet maltiness with gentle, roasty, charred finish that lasts. Medium-light body. Bottle sampled with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

The Lure : Creamy grapes of a candied nature protrude the malts roastiness and the yeasts apricot allusions.

The Festivities : Diplomatic roasted malt bitterness meditating about its dryness and its fondness for raisins.

Transcendence : An old wooden cabin deep in the forest is a great place to roast some malt.

Dark brown pour. Decent light brown head, creamy around the glass sides. Interesting malty aroma. Coffee and smoked malts hints, quite mild and pleasant through a light floral dark honey aspect. Dark malts attack in mouth, hard to point up flavors, but tasty. Almost like burnt caramel maltiness and a coating grassy and coffee-like roastiness turning into a mildly bitter finish. Very soft bodied, smooth carbonation. Very good.

Really nice, I could drink alot of this, alone or with food, its a good schwarzbier.  Garnet color, muddled with brown, full head.  Aroma and flavor are complemented with caramel, toasted nuts, and semi-sweet chocolates.  A bit of a spicy finish tops it off.  Semi-dry palate aids drinkability.

bottle.  Pours a dark, dark chocolate color with a moderate head and nice lacing.  Rich, smooth mouthfeel and not too much carbonation.  This is only my second brew from Sprecher and this brewer is quickly becoming a favorite.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2005 Ive had this both in the bottle and on tap at Sprecher.  Very good stuff.  Nice head that floats on top and leaves its mark on the glass as you work your way down.  A rich, chocolate malt with a slightly bitter finish with coffee undertones.  Highly recommended.

Opaque, black. Creamy beige head of generous proportions. Excellent lace.  Robust, malty aroma of licorice, chocolate, coffee & dark fruit. Soft, creamy feel. Complex malty flavour of licorice, chocolate, coffee & dark fruit. Low bitterness but some spicy hops are evident.

black see through pour with a minimal grey head. roasty malt aroma that is sweet, flavor is roastyand sweet and bitter finish. chocolate notes, thick mouthfeel of syrup. nice underneath fruity plum flavor.
Poured black with thin tan head...smelled quite roasty with some coffee overtones...taste was a little thin, but definate roasty malty sweet...mildly bitter hop finish...

Dark nut brown color.  Pleasant enough malty aroma, with the aroma and flavor fitting nicely into the schwarzbier profile.  Rich caramel and roasted notes, some coffee-like flavors but not quite there.  Standard palate, some carbonation.  I enjoy schwarzbiers, perhaps because they remind me of what milds aim at--some dark and rich but not going whole hog down the stout road.
Nice, tan, creamy lasting head. Black,opaque brew.Strong burnt grain flavor. Pleasant aftertaste. Malt is nicely balanced with the hops.  A smooth, refreshing drink. Ill return to this one.
Caramel, malt and treacle in the aroma. Dark brown, pours an enormous cappuccino head. Flavours of subtle chocolate malt, some coffee too. Quite bitter, full bodied. A fine example!
Bottle. Malty, medium tongue, slight malt bite. Notes of coffee, roasted malts, and barley come through. Very good use of hops. This would be a nice session beer.

This one is a real winner.  Pours a nice opaque black with a tan head that refuses to wilt.  Aroma is of roasted malt.  Tastes is of a robust dark malt and coffee.  Real strong flavorful beer, but is still so  smooth that it goes down real easy.  wonderful Full bodies, full flavored yet easy drinking beer...

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2006 A soothing kind of a brew, this purs out almost black with a brownish head.  The aroma is of dark roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Very rich caramel toffee & coffee malts to be tasted.  A nifty slighty tart finish rounds out an all-around great drink.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Tree Inn, Blue Island, IL<font size=-1>

extremely dark with a lovely dark tan head.  lots of carbonation, too much carbonation i think.  plenty of coffee and dark malts, some smoke.  burnt/caramelized candy, good rich thick malt presence and a touch of bitterness to finish.  excellent!

In the glass, this beer is dark , almost black in color.  Topped by a creamy tan head.  The aroma is of chocolate and black coffee.  Flavor profile is chocolate, a hint of dark molasses.  The beer was well carbonated.

Pours jet black, with an off white head. Very black color to it. Aroma was strong including malts and choclate. Flavor was very full and covered the palate. Raost malt, choclate and sweet milk/cofee detected. Very filling beer. First of the Style...

Appearance: dark brown, inching toward black color, coppery-red at foot of glass, head is a triumph, all puffy, creamy, cocoa-tan in color.
Aroma: deep and darkly fruity, warm and toasty,yet creamy, soft, yet earthy, definite nut character, plus cocoa, and and a candyish feel, making it feel like a slightly carbonated, sweet mocha latte.
Taste: warm mouthfeel, ample texture, giving, full of character, dark, yes, but a most companionable brew, slinks and sashays through the mouth, flirting with all the senses. Chocolate dabbles in, nuts flitter around like a social butterfly at play in the senses, and oh, so smooth. Resilient finish, stays solidly and happily on the palate. Wonderfully thick & tasty texture.
What I love about this beer is that you very easily forget that youre actually drinking a lager, for it is so full-bodied and flavorful, youd think you had a brown ale or a porter in your hands. Theres only the slightest bitterness, but the flavor looms so huge...sassafras? sasparilla? anise? molasses?...that it ranks high on drinkability.
This has got to be the best schwarzbier Ive ever had, and Id be only too happy to try any challengers. If they can taste better than this, bring em on!!
Just recently had this on tap for the first time, where it rocked!

This baby is a perfect "knock off" of German beers. From the bottle and its contents it is hard to believe it is crafted right here in the US of A. Pours black with a rich deep aroma of toffee and prunes. Very bock-like. Rich toffee malts with coffee overtones. Hops come through bitterly and balanced. Drinks deep and hearty. Carbonation is right on. This is a fine beverage. I especially like the fact that all Sprecher beers are served in true drinking proportions.

Thanks to CaptainCougar for this fine trade!
Deep mahogany ringed with ruby at the edges which supports a creamy large mocha colored head.
Coffee like bitterness at first which becomes more roasty as it passes the tongue. Just enough underlying sweetness to balance the bitter notes nicely. Refreshing and smooth. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2004 Bottle pours black with brown highlights, small off-white milk froth like head, lively carbonation, with fairly attractive carbonation.   Toasted malts, toffee, and butter on the nose.   Roasted malts, even a light soy on the tongue.   Smooth mouthfeel, slightly creamy.   Finishes with a nice burnt malt flavor, but not much of the coffee, caramel, or chocolate that they mention.   Either way, this is a very tasty Schwarzbier!   Thanks goes out to CaptainCougar for the trade!
Poured a dark black with an averaged sized tan head. Aroma and tastes of coffee and chocolates. A decent beer and Im glad the family I stayed at in Milwaukee had this in their fridge at the time.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2004 Tap into pint glass, Sheffields (Chicago).  Ive seen this beer everywhere around Chicago, but Ive never had it.  Im glad that I chose it this time.  Beautiful butterscotch aroma that was mighty strong.  Pure black in the glass (it might actually be lighter, but it was dark outside in the beer garden) with ruby at the edges; a beige, creamy head.  The mouthfeel was as expected, creamy and full, just the right balance of watery refreshment and mouthfilling substance.  Flavor was the same butterscotch, definite caramel notes, and some understated hops.  Would be a good beer to pair with ice cream, and maybe pork.
Black as advertized.  Soft on the tounge, the flavor is bitter molasses.  This is a comforting beer.  The bitter finish doesnt go away but as it lingers it gets slightly peppery.  Nice stuff.
A very good, dark beer.  Pours nice with a moderate tan head.  Aroma and flavor of toasted coffee and chocolate.  Well carbonated but a bit thin in the finish.  Very enjoyable.
bittersweet atertaste but better than a stout. Molasses taste and aroma. Bit of chocolate and coffee. Session ale.
Dark Coloring. Big White Head.  Chocolate. Malty. Maybe a bit salty.  Very Creamy....damned fine dark beer.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 Not to much aroma on the first whiff, it got chocolately on the second pass. Chocolate malty taste, wonderful smooth mocha aftertaste. All this hangs around till the end. I cant envision a schwarzbier any better than this.

Thicker and more interesting (complex, even?) than most Schwarzbiers.  For some reason, the taste of this beer reminds me of a freshly baked, crisp and salty pretzel.  Bread dough, lightly sour with a salty ending; very light roasts, sweet dark malts, a little hoppy at the edges.
This is the best Schwarzbier I have ever tried. Much better than the German versions and extremely malty as I think it ought to be. Now I just missed the biergarten and a bavarian orchestra.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 Bottle... This beer rocks!... Very dark, crimson ale with a small, creamy, white head. Smoky and chocolaty nose. Very well-balanced, delicious, roasted flavor with notes of coffee and dark chocolate. Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Lengthy, moderately bitter finish. Extremely nice brew!

Looks wonderful in the glass, deep and dark, full tan head. Malty aroma, chocolate, caramel, a little bit of roasty coffee as well. Similar flavor, very full flavored and well rounded out. Complex and balanced just right. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Worthy of being a top schwarzbier.

Dark black, opaque, faint ruby comes through against a light. Tannish head good lace.  Chocolate, coffee, Roasted malt aromas...Creamy smooth beer w/slightly sweet roasty finish, medium/light body...Nice malty beer, good roasty chocoalate nutty character w/o being overpowering or astringent, well-rounded...maybe just some slighy hop spice in the toffee/carmel finish. A really drinkable dark lager with good depth.

Super deep brown, hint of crimson, tan creamy lasting head.  Nose reminds me a bit of a wee heavy.  Roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, coffee, and a slight hint of smoke. Flavors are rich, malty coffeeish, chocolate,and again a hint of smoke at the end.  Even some hops decide to play and do their best to balance, and they do. Full bodied, soft carbonation, coffee like finish.  This is a helluva beer! :-)

Used to bad mouth Sprecher beers but they are not bad, really.  This had a deep, dark brown body with a nice tan head.  Roasted grain in the nose.  Coffee.  Burnt coffee.  Full bodied.  Rich, full, satisfying taste.  Would definitely drink this again.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2005 Deep shades of mahogany and crimson, pleasant almost sweet aroma shaping up to be a great schwarzbier!  Taste is first rate!  Lots of roasty malts, caramel and coffee, great stuff. A very good beer. Pleasant taste for pleasant times.

My first schwarzbeer. Its interesting because I was surprised by an initial dryness I dont normally associate with lagers. The dryness made me think this tastes much like a porter or stout but halfway through the glass a malt sweetness comes to the fore. The malt is definitely very German-like, which, to my taste, seems a little foreign to the stout-like dryness. A lot of roast coffee, some faint caramel, in both aroma and taste. The color is interesting, too--looks like a heavy stout from the side looks more translucent and ruby-brown when you look down into the glass as you drink. I poured this into a glass from Germany, an 0.4l tulip with a logo fro Alpirsbacher Klosterbrau Pilsner aus dem Schwarzwal. The head was big and rose about two inches above the rastal line and subsided rather quickly as I drank, leaving almost no lace or residual foam on the beer. Overall, I like this although maybe not enough to call it a favorite.
Dark reddish-brown body, small tan head, mild roasty nose. Dry, bitter, roasty, with chocolate notes. Good mouthfeel.

Nice appearance with the beer pouring dark brown with some ruby highlights.  A big light tan head sits atop the beer and is well retained.  Aroma is roasted malt, with coffee and caramel notes.  Flavor is mouth filling with coffee and roasted nuts flavors detected.  This is the one of the most flavorful lagers I have ever had.  Thanks to CaptainCouger for trading.
Deep brown in color with ruby highlights and a thick off-white head.Bready,chocolately malt aroma. Flavor is of bread,chocolate and malt.
Dark redish brown, with a nice tan head. Malty aroma with hints of dark fruits and chocolate. Malty with a very slight hint of raisin and some bitter sweet cocoa. Not bad.

Pours with a light brown, three-finger head that goes slowly and leaves a good lace.  Light to medium carbonation.  Very dark almost black ruby color.  Nose is chocolate malt. Starts with a rich coffee and chocolate flavor.  Finish is sweet with some hops. $1.95 for a 16oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.

Has a tinted froth and a bit of a smokey twinge to it.  Quite dark indeed.  A solid pint at the end of the day, perhaps, but not one I'd have over serious discussion or even watching the game... its just too involved of a beer.
A reasonable American facsimile of good Bavarian schwarzbier.  The color is correctly similar to coffee, the aroma is of light hops.  Decent, not great.

3/2/04:  bottle.  solid and brown in color with a thin tan head.  sweet caramel malt nose.  nicely balanced hop/malt flavors.  heavy on the malt, fairly roasted and just slightly bitter.  nice leave with tones of coffee.

An amazingly good Black lager.

On the pour:dark black ruby in colour,slight tan head with minimal lacing.Nose is sharp and hoppy,with burnt malt.

On taste:well this is good.huge malt kick with nuts and smoke to start,then into noble hops to dry the palate and set it up for the finish...prune,earth,bitter lemon,semi sweet Carmel,and a mix of clove and a dry hop.Wow.

This is a real good black lager,perhaps the best I have tried,It is a beer I just roll around on my tongue as it is a little too complex to break down in one beer.

med/high carbonation and very good body for the style.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2004 A beautiful near black with mahogany highlights and a thick diminishing light brown head.  Aroma of roast, caramel, chocolate, espresso and vanilla.    Medium thick creamy body with a moderate amount of carbonation.  Nice, malty bittersweet flavor of coffee, chocolate, lots of roast, smoke, licorice, salt and malted milk.  Very good.
Dark full body with frothy off-white head and good lacing.  It had a sweet coffee smell that I didn't care for.   Taste was more on the coffee side than I care to have.  Good beer.

Dark, dark body with a frothy tan head. Nice lacing.
Huge chocolate, roast and coffee aromas dominate.
Wonderful full malty flavors. Slightly fruity.
The smoothest beer I've ever had. Ever!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2004 Very dark with a nice small biege head that lingers. Some chocolate and coffee in the aroma. Fairly full in the mouth. Caramel and and coffee in the flavor. I missed the salty note that others mentioned. Also has some black pepper spice in the finish. Very well done. I think that people who think that US brews are lacking should try this.

Deep ruby black, nice light tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, roasted grain nose.  Sweet, roasted grain, coffee like, a bit of soy suace lingering, pleasant body/mouthfeel, finishing almost salty, a bit acidic, with hops doing their job well.  This seems very highly rated to me, am I missing something?

opaque black color with a thick light brown head.  wonderful aroma of roasted malts, coffee and espresso, chocolate, and a hint of carmel sweetness.  thick head is lasting...medium body.  very smooth on the palate, chewy.  Carmel and coffee are very apparent in the flavor along with the roasted malts and chocolate, very complex and wonderful flavors.  finish is smooth and creamy with low carbonation throughout.

Deep, dark as black olives pour with a creamy mocha colored head. Has a bit of a olive oil-like aroma to it (olives on my mind for some reason) with some coffee notes as well. Chewy, salty flavor, with some good malty accents with a bittersweet chocolate finish. Very smooth palate, goes down extremely smooth. Alcohol hidden well. Very good Schwarzbier. Many thanks to Aurelius for bringing this back from Chicago.

Bottle: Ok nose, cream, ash, and smoke. Reddish brown black color. Small head. Bittersweet flavor. Smoke, carmel, coffee all come to mind. Smooth and creamy. Really enjoyable, Very drinkable. Seems classic
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: This beer started a little poorly -- the initial aroma smells distinctly of canned creamed corn mixed with stout.  That either fades after a while or I got used to it, and the aroma goes malty. Good translucent black with a beady head.  Good pint bottle, minor ding for the twistoff, but an authentic German feel to the label.  Nice roasty coffee and dark cocoa flavor, good light sweetness, good acid balance.  Medium bodied, roastiness lingers but isn't overpowering on the backend.  It's a very good value at $4.99 for 4 pints -- being unfamiliar with the brew, I thought that it might have been $4.99 per beer at Sam's Wine & Spirits in Chicago. If the aroma was a bit better, it would have been an all-star.

Finally found this interesting lager.  Pours dark but (barely) translucent red-brown with a thin light tan head.  Very caramely and bready/yeasty aroma.  Toasty, roasty flavor profile with caramels and breads mixing with a touch of dark chocolate.  Very yeasty.  A creamy lager reminiscent of bready maibocks.

The only Sprecher I purchase, because I think that this is far and way their best product. So black that you almost miss the deep red coloring, this malty brew is smooth and satisfying.  This black lager could use a little more head, but that's about all that I would change.  Nice job, Sprecher.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Wow! I wasn't expecting such strong roasted flavor in this beer. Along with a slight smokey flavor, this beer is very tasty. Dark black appearance with a medium tan head. Yeasty, roasted aroma. Terriffic beer.

Maybe the best dark lager I've had in years. Nearly black with a thick head and excellent retention. Aroma is of roasted malt with a smokiness in the background. Body is full and smooth and the flavor of this brew is fantastic. Smoky malt with notes of chocolate and dark roast coffee. Finishes with a slight bitterness which adds some balance. Thanks CaptainCougar for this excellent brew!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: dark with only a tad of red tint..a dark brown head..lagery, salty, dark chocolate aroma..saly peanut skins and dark malts and lager yeast flavors...dark chocolate..yet bitter...solid brew however.

Dark reddish brown hue with small tan head and some lace. The aroma hinted of toasted pumpernickel bread, light molasses, caramel, aromatic and noble hops. ripe apples, sweet spices, and smoke. The taste starts with a mocha malt and earthy yeast notes. Has an undertone of acidic fruits and mild bitterness. The finish provides more flavor profiles of smoke and coffee. The mouthfeel is lively and slightly metallic, dry and crisp. Refreshing and quaffable as long as you enjoy the smoky nature of a Schwarzbier, which I can.

My rating for this brew went through the wash, so I will have piece it together from what I can still read and from memory. I couldn't make out my Flavor and Palate ratings but they should be accurate within one point. Rich milk chocolate aroma. Deep ruby reddish brown color with large, small-bubble, light brown head. Excellent lace. Knowing that Oakes had touted this one highly, I was eager to try it. It didn't dissapoint. I look forward to verifying my rating in the near future.

Draft. Among the pale pilseners at the downtown Chicago Kristkindl market is a keg of pale pilsener's evil twin. Pours with a hearty brown head over a body that looks solid black in a plastic cup, then shows brown highlights as I drink it. Kind of a black bread smell thats not as prominent as a stout. Definite dark roast malts against a German hop profile. Leaves a taste at the back of the palate where bitterness and astingency are detected. Roast coffee taste, perhaps a note of pear, subdued by its "clean" lager finish. Brings up a bit of a burnt toast taste toward the end that may not be to everyone's liking, but I like its complexity.

Thanks are graciously extended to BigBadBear63 for the hook up on this brew!
Bottled: 12/12/02    Hot damn, this puppy pours beautifully! A rich dark brown body with edges of crimson, the head is an enormous mound of toffee cushion.   The aroma and flavors are full and malty, although very earthy as well, nose of warm peat fields, carrot juice, stewed roast beef – peppercorns & cabbage, thick roasted barley, hints of chocolate. This may sound disgusting, but truth be told, it is a rather surprisingly tasty and enjoyable Black Beer! Thanks for the surprise Mike!
Black beer with a thick head of nice foam.  Nice malty aroma with touches of sweetness.  Nice malt flavor with predictible sweet twinges.  Nice fullness.  Good beer.

This dark brown to black brew is topped by a medium thick to thick tan head with a decent amount of lacing left on the glass.  The aroma is slightly sweet and malty with a very slight smokiness and an odd grainy(?) note. Something just doesn't fit right in the nose.  The flavor is slightly sweet, roasty and malty.  Thankfully, whatever put the nose off, wasn't in the flavor.  A slight hoppy bitterness is also observed.  Medium bodied and smooth.
Mild aroma of roasted malt.  Aroma seems to have an "off" chemical element.  Black of course, with some red.  Large head.  Flavors of medium bodied roasted malt with some sweetness.

(bottled) Black with a light tan head.  Toasted malt & molasses aroma. Creamy medium-full bodied beer with black patent malt dominating the palette.  Molasses, chocolate, caramel (in decreasing amounts) underlying flavor: is the bitterness from hops or black malt astringency?  Spicy hop finish.

Bottle pours a deep dark ruby color that is seen only with bright back lighting.  The head is a tan to off white rocky froth that sustains for some time.  The aroma is subtle, but toasty and dark.  The flavor is quite nice and roasted with just a hint of toasted malt and some chocolate and a slight hop finish.  The palate is rich and smooth with some nice carbonation to provide a cleansing of the mouth.  Overall, I like this and my introduction to the Schwarzbier category.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2014 Black, hints of ruby and deep brown creep through the sunlight at the edges, nice creamy head that slowly fades.  Aroma is actually a bit on the hoppy side, hint of vegetation over malt sweetness.  Its been far too many years since I tasted one of these.  Flavor is of smooth chocoaltes, a hint of caramel, and a drying hoppy finish, a bit spicy and earthy.  Quaffable and wonderful.  Why does Sprecher taunt me by sending root beer to Virginia but not their high octane stuff?  RERATE:  Slightly stunned to find this on tap at Commercial.  Tasting notes the same! Rating the same! Hops just more floral than I had recalled.  Still a sentimental favorite.
Great dark beer.  Reminds me of the type of beer which turned me on to beer.  Thick head.  Nice malty dark taste.  Good stuff.

Bottle 

What appears to be black is actually dark brown with garnet highlights.  Clarity is about as good as its going to get with a brew this dark.  Creamy tan head that leaves good lacing.  The aroma is quite subdued, but I detect some coffee, caramel, and earthiness.  The flavor is extremely smooth, with more earthy flavor than anything else.  Theres some coffee, chocolate, caramel, and faint hop, but they take a backseat to the rustic malt richness.  Finishes like it began, along with a hint of licorice.  Medium in body, with a soothing dryness and slight acidity on the tail end.  A top-notch Schwarzbier!

black with some ruby/garnet shining through. thick head (light brown). aroma is quite grainy...i really wish i could put my finger exactly on what is the cause of the scent..i'd love to pinpoint that bastard exactly. fairly sour yeasty effect in the mouth..finish is a combo of the mild hop bitterness, and the caramel finally shows up.

Dark brown colour with ruby highlights and a think light brown head. Nice powerful aroma of a crazy complxity: hops, grapes, roasted malt, yeast & bread. Light-bodied; Strong roasted malt flavours, hints of coffee with the yeastiness & slight sweetnesspicked up in the nose. Aftertaste bittered from the roasted malt & coffee flavour. Overall, an odd beer that turns out to be nicely complex, but still be on for the style! Definately one to try! I got this in a trade from CaptainCougar in sixteen ounce form. Thanks again Tom!

This was actually pretty cool. I typically am not a fan of this style of beer but this was pretty good. Black as night with a thick frothy head that leavs a good amount of lacing on the glass. Malts in the nose and flavor with a smoothe texture and medium bodied mouth.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2004 Reminds me more of a creme soda than a beer. Otherwise, this is my first Schwarzbier and I really liked it - although, I haven't developed a sense that will explain why this is so special. light in flavor yet dark, but good. i need to re-rate. UPDATE 9/24/04: i finally am trying this again! this black beer is refreshing! immediately i'm within an onslaught of flavor: mint chocolate and coffee with a little saltiness (bacon!) as it warms... it's creamy, smooth, and delicious. definitely uprated... this is shiznizzlicous.

Wow.  This is one tasty lager.  Deep ruby/black color with a minimal tan head.  Rich caramel malt flavor with strong chocolate malt flavor.  Slight bitterness.  Very well crafted and enjoyable.  Deduct a point for the twist off cap.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 Had at Sprecherfest 2003.  Its most noticeable component is its chocolately flavor; give it a try.  

7/4/05 - A smooth roasty, choclatey beer.  The savior of summerfest!

The color a deep incarnadine with a resplendent head that is a winsome light tan, the texture that of whipped cream and as it disintegrates a glutinous sheet of lace welds itself to the glass. Nose is deeply malt with hints of toasted grain, somewhat sweet a real treat to the senses. The start is malt-laden and ambrosial with the top intermediate in its feel to the palate. Finish is prickly in its acidity, the hops purposeful in their spiciness, quite dry and lingering aftertaste. A real treat for me as its been years since Ive had a beer from this magnificent brewery.

This brew poured a large head of light brown mostly lasting bubbles that left a semi-transparent brown colored body with no apparent carbonation behind.  It had a mild malt aroma and an initially smooth palatethat finished with a mild hop afterbite.  Its flavor was lightly malted.
Nose is sweet lager, earthy. Taste has a great balanced mouthfeel. Flavor is slightly sour with a dominating roasty presence that clings to the mouth. An enjoyable beer.

Color pours brown out of the stubbie brown pint bottle, settles nearly black, has a definate deep brown tone up to the light with ruby highlights. An inch high tan head of loose bubbly spongyness grew fast but faded nearly just as fast to a thin ring and minimal spotty lace. 

Nose is roasty malts, slightly tangy of dark fruits and molasses with a touch of chocolate and light mustyness.

Has a complex mix of malts with alot of roastyness, has a bit of caramel and molasses, a very light touch of chocolate and very mild bitterness, quite smooth the whole way through. Some slight dark fruity tangyness and a smokey burntness pokes through close to the finish. Very subtle and well layered in its complexity.

Feel is solid medium body smoothness picks up some fullness in the middle and finishes smooth, lightly crisp with a mellow tangy smokey lingering dryness. An incredibly drinkable, yummy showing of the style; well rounded and smooth.

Some reddish tints around the edge of the glass for this otherwise black beer.  Dark malt, dust, earth and grit nose.  Same in flavors with grain, malt and slightly roasted flavors.  It's like an earthenware pot.  Smooth.

Rich, thick, and malty like they tried stuffing a few beers into just one.  So creamy and filling with tons of chocolate and coffee and hints of smokiness and marshmellow sweetness.  One of the finest beers in all of Brewerland!!!
An wonderful schwarzbier. Rich and malty with some tasty chocolate and coffee notes. A touch of hops in the finish. I find I like this best served a bit cold.

Sampled on draught.  Very malty aroma, Pumpernickel bread, roasty and grainy, some slight, spicy hop and faint toffee.  Deep, dark, clear mahogany color with a creamy, ivory head.  Flavor is likewise very grainy and roasty, but with some caramel/toffee sweetness and spice.  Finishes dry and with a flourish of Hallertau hops.  Smooth, creamy texture.  Great stuff, I never thought a Schwarz could be this tasty.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2004 Ruby brown with a medium creamy tan head.  Not much aroma, but what is there is lightly sweet, very smooth mouthfeel.  Ends sweet.  I found this beer to be boring without much going on.

It poured into the glass a very dark brown color w/ some reddish bricking. It was translucent. The head was a tightly bubbled tan color that started out quite large and diminished slowly. The nose had some heavy, sweet, malty tones in it. The flavor has a touchy of smokiness along w/ some hoppy notes. Very enjoyable, very drinkable. Thanks CaptainCouger

The epitome of Schwarz (says the man who has tried one or two others?- Hah!) Incredibly smooth and creamy with a thin lasting small bubbled head. Smoke plus caramel plus a bit of rock salt in the flavor - almost milky in the palate - gorgeous dark dark ruby color - mellow and delightful - perfect bitterness closes this gem - wow, what a surprise - this is a phenomenal middle-sized (I presume) brewery.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Strong coffee flavor and aroma with a nice balance of bitterness and dark chocolate.  Very creamy and roasty - a nice brew.  Leaves a nice pleasant cocoa essence in the mouth.  Very dark reddish brown with a little, but lasting head.  My only complaint is that the flavor is not quite as robust as it could be.

Poured out of bottle, bought at Sam's Wine & Spirits in Chicago, 6/3/03.  Light tan, tight head dissipates quickly.  Very dark reddish-brown color-- almost totally opaque, but nice-looking.  Nose is of a dark roasted malt, with some scent of springy berries-- almost like a sweet or even an imperial stout.  First taste is a dark roast, again malty with some tingly fruitiness.  Pleasant undertaste of caramel too, with all of the chocolate and dark coffee of, again, a fine imperial stout.  Medium-light body, surprisingly thin for as strong as the nose and flavor are, but surprisingly long finish (roast all the way, almost burnt flavor, with some nice nuttiness that creeps through) for as thin as it feels in the mouth.  This stuff goes down extremely smooth, but somehow lingers for a very long time.  Alcohol flavor is there a bit, but is not off-putting.  Flavor brightens up strongly as you work through a bottle (and as it warms up a bit).  Very welcome addition to the lager canon.

I would have guessed this to be a stout or a porter, but a dark lager?  Never.  The head is tan and frothy, and the aroma is roasty and chocolately.  The flavor is quite malty and complex, with intense roasted/smoke flavors, caramel, coffee, licorice, and some others I can't quite identify.  If all schwarzbeirs were like this, I'd be trying them a lot more often.
Nice coffee/caramel aroma and flavor. Very dark, definitely a schwarzbier yet smoooth.
Very dark beer with great Malty flavor.  Nice thick tan head.  I like Sprecher beers because they are served in 16 oz bottles.  A very smooth Schwarzbier.
Nice and malty, fair carbonation, very coffee-like.  I like, but not a "must have".
Smooth silky mouth feel.  Oh and its black in color - looks like a stout and taste like stout, with much coffee favor.  Good Beer

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2003 Deep dark ruby color with a big frothy head.  A very unusual aroma of earthy toasted hay with coffee suggestions.  There is and initial bitterness that is quite forceful, more of an ESB bitter than an overhopped bitter as this retains its creaminess throughout.  Very seductive, the aroma keeps begging you to identify it by giving you a different scent with each sip.  Stout like flavors but not as heavy.  The micros in Wisconsin make excellent lagers.
This beer had nice aroma and color. The flavor was fairly complex and delicious, though not QUITE as much depth of body as I had hoped for. A fine beer, nevertheless.

Dark black color. Medium head. Aroma is roasted coffee. Medium bodied. Deeply roasted malts. Chocolate is the predominate flavor, but there is a touch of coffee and nuts. Somewhat earthy tones as well. Slightly sweet. Somewhat porter like. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

This is inviting.  Lots of charcoal grill flavor with restrained sweetness at the beginning.  As I work my way through the glass, I get some nice vegetal notes, finishing grainy dry.  Very nice light fruit and hop flavor show up at the end.  Complex dark malt and spice hop aroma throughout.  Excellent.  Huge thanks to Howie.
Very dark lager.. nice, rich lager... the darkest I've ever had.  Great mouthfeel, darn near like that of a stout, but even smoother. yum
Dark, Dark brown. . .just kidding, it's black.  Strange hoppy aroma, sort of sugary and chocolatey. . . lingering bitter taste, slightly spicy . . .a most interesting selection.
Draught.  Surprize, its black.  Theres also a touch of red and no head.  Sweet chocolate, anise, coffee and nut.  The lightest touch of hops in the finish to round this beer out.

Black color, as you probably would have guessed. Nice sized head, with a cream color to it. Kind of a roasted coffeeish smell. The taste doesnt have as much coffee in it as Id expected, although it is certainly present. Im tasting quite a bit of smoke, and a little caramel/chocolate too. A good blend of flavors, without being too complex. Nice creamy body. Very enjoyable beer.

Very interesting - very vegetative, as in mushrooms and fermenting corn.  Lots of peanut too.  Things I have never tasted in a beer before, thats for sure.  Coffee, yeast as well.  Unique, I liked it.
Nice, dark color.  Flavors of coffee & roasted malts with hints of chocolate.  Very Good.
Very nice malt profile: roasted grains, bitter chocolate, coffee.  Very bold and solid beer--enjoyable.

Deep dark ruby, approaching almost black. Thin, creamy head and lace. Nose of roasted barley, bakers chocolate, coffee grounds, walnuts and others. Thin to medium bodied. Nice black malty twangs with addicitng coffee like roastiness, underlying caramel sweetness, walnuts, subtle chocolate and more. A bit dry in finish and a nice lingering finish. Worth a stab if your a fan of the style. Missing something to really catapult it IMO.

A very good attempt at the style!  Not as carbonated as I would have liked though.  The flavor kicked ass!  Sweet, roasted malts, chocolate flavor...sort of thin in the body considering the bold flavors it had, but it all came together to make a great tasting beer.
Nice brew,long lasting tan head with a malty,coffee aroma the same in the flavor with a slight hint of chocolate nice finish with a coffee aftertaste,nice brew.

Very nice beer.Head is solid and tan, but thin and dissipates fairly quickly. Color is a deep red appearing black untill held up to the lights. Very drinkable, with strong chocolate and coffee flavors.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2004 Deep black, some neat legs near the glass.  Head left me too quickly, but nice while it remained.  Well roasted nose with creamy malts behind it.  good balance and character.  Hints of smokiness, lots of roasted barley.  Hints of chocolate and caramel sweetness.  Really a great bier!!!!!  Full body, great mouthfeel and a beautiful presentation.
Great, smooth body.  Hints of caramel for sure with a touch of coffee and no chocolate.  A little unbalanced towards the sweet side.

The first time I tried this beer, i was pleasently surprised by the complex flavors that I found.  It seemed to fill my mouth as i drank it and the taste was excellent.  Not as bitter as I was expecting from a beer of this color.  A little pricey, but it comes in 16oz four packs to make up for this.

Very nice pour: Opaque, with a very long-lasting and smooth head.  Lots of chocolate and caramel maltiness with a bit of coffee flavor as well.  Its sort of like a combination of a bock and a stout.  Quite sweet and nice, smooth finish.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2007 Re-rate on 3/6/07.  Im glad I finally have a chance to re-rate this after so many years.  And now Im in my kitchen, not an Old Chicago!  Totally black color with a... no, no the head is now gone.  Sweet malt yet smoky aroma.  Can something smell salty?  Beautiful taste of slightly roasted malt, a pinch of burned malt, chocolate, caramel, smoke and earth.  Its like a lagered dry stout.  Freakin sweet!  Well, its pretty dry, but... yeah, you understand.  Right?

Original Rating on 10/23/02; 6-5-7-3-15.  Use the Schwartz!  Not too shabby, has a faint chocolate flavor I think.  Recommendation: Sprecher seems to have issues with their bottles.  Everything I have ever tried from them is rancid in the bottle, fine out of it.  Always pour it in a glass.
I had my first taste at the Sprecher Tour. A delicious dark that brings out the quality of a finely made dark lager.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2005 rerate-another one of my old ratings that i just had to redo.  pours black like a porter-92% black with a beige head.  dark malt aroma-not very complex.  flavors of smoke, chocolate, roast and burnt malt.  this is still the only schwarz i have had to date.  I still think this is a great beer, but maybe not as good as i remembered it the first time.  a bit oxidized in the finish.  chocolate notes come out more as it warmed.  somewhat thin body.
This beer is the epitome of the perfect pour.  Dark color with a great head.  Once you take the first sip, it gets even better.  Easily one of my top 5 beers.
A fine dark lager that can be drank a session beer.   Definite "porter-esque" aroma and taste.   I would take this beer over a Black & Tan any day.

nice schwarz.
dark brown with a thin head, malty nose.
taste is full of malt and caramel. hasa hoppy finish witha fruit aftertaste.
complex and light simultaneously.

very good in flavor and in taste.

not enough words to describe this awesome tasting beer

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2004 August 2002:  Perfect large, creamy head (medium-diminishing) atop a coal-black medium-thick body.  Chocolate-espresso nose, very malty, little grainy lager smell.  Flavor earthy, chocolaty, but somewhat on the sour/rancid side.  Bad bottle?  Really not all that good tasting, though it improves a bit in the finish.  7/4/5/2/11 2.9 
Dec 2004, Swedish dregs, Alts etc tasting w/MartinT, tiggmtl and Rastacouere #16.  16 oz bottle.  Dark walnut-black, nearly opaque...sweet molasses an wonderful smoke in the nose...sugar in the mouth dies quickly, replaced by strong but restrained roastiness...much better than before, either a better bottle or a better handle on the style by me.
Richly opaque with a nice maltiness and creamy tan head.  Good hop bitterness as well.
Not one of Sprechers best.  Aroma is rich, but taste is very sharp and quickly gone.
Very good dark lager.  Malt depth only achieved by true decoction mash.  Almost like a hard pretzel character.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2004 Big and malty.  High, lasting tan head.  Hugely malty: roasty and chocolatey.  Manages to remain smooth and drinkable despite quite a bit of caramel-malt sweetness.  Porterish malt profile, but definitely a lager.

Sprecher is a good brewery with a few sanitation problems.  This beer is great in a fresh keg, but i have had too many bottles with floaties and rancid sour character to buy it that way again.  Still, when it is good, it is very good and not a common style to find in the USA.  Smooth Black and lightly sweet.  I base my rating on getting in on draft down on State Street in Madison.
Malty, rich, and bitter, Black Bavarian is a very unique beer -- you think it should be sweet, but its not at all. The aftertaste is unusual.
I am not a big stout beer fan and that is what this stuff atsed like. But  it was good, dont get me wrong.
Has a mild, malty aroma wafting off its pitch black body. Flavor is light but complex, dominated by roasty, chocolatey malt flavors and the flavors of good pumpernickel bread.
Excellent black beer.  I really love this style, though its hard to come across good examples of it.  I would certainly recommend this one.

Lager, porter, stout, beer of some sort.  I know its a lager, but it had me confused.  Very porter-like in appearance and taste.  Coffee taste is prevelent but not overwhelming.  Lots of malt in this one.  I liked it.
Overrated.  Has anyone actually tasted this beer? Its way too malty to drink more than one.
Strong mocha/coffee aroma, slightly hoppy.  Flavors are a touch artificial to me, and moderately cloying.  Nonetheless, very drinkable.
I really like the malty flavor in this one.  Distinctly German tasting.  The mixture of chocolate and caramel flavors is superb.  Very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2008 Big frothy head, strong malt taste and aftertaste.  Very smooth and drinkable for a dark thick beer.  
Re-rate 5-23-08: This beer is sadly a shadow of its former self. Much thinner and less flavorful than I remember. Too bad they had to ruin such a good thing. I am actually afraid to try the Special Amber again!

I had this beer at the Sprecher brewery about six years ago and took four bottles back to Minneapolis to savor.  My rating is based on faulty memory.  I remember it being rich and malty, without being overly sweet. I remember it as being nearly the best that I tasted at Sprecher .
Yes, one of Sprechers best.  Its to bad they changed the recipe a few years ago.  It was even better then.
Very malty. Nice biscuit and chocolate flavors. A littel thin. A pretty good beer but im not much of a lager guy.
Basically exactly what I expected...strong caramel/chocolate malt flavor but a thin body. Smooth but too thin to be a clasic in my book.
Creamy, flavorful, delicious beer. Awesome brewing.
Sprechers best... and near World Class. Bracing and soothing at the same time. The maltiness is amazing, the aroma like toast. The real strong stuff.
Barely translucent. Aroma of coffee and chocolate malt.  Exceptionally clean roasted malty taste.  A very good dark lager.
Alternating rolls of sweet (tofee) and bitter (coffee) in a proud dark brew.
quite a tonic
Great stuff. chocolate roasted  flavors with a hint of smokiness. I should of bought all 4 bottles. I think i will go get them. This is the stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2005 Ive had this on tap and in a bottle, and I really enjoy drinking it. This beer joins a list of brews which, I feel, need no improvement whatsoever. Thus, a perfect score. On tap this is just a fabulous quaf. It has a creamy, smoky richness that makes a luscious dessert.

This is my first Sprecher aside from thier excelent Root Beer. Very nice and suprisingly subtle. Malty with a burnt but not burned chocalate taste. As a hop head I would like a bit more though it would not fit the style. Fun beer.

Finally found a store in Michigan that stocks Wisconsin micros (Oliver Ts in Grand Blanc).  As a result, I can rate beers that my palate only distantly remembers from the years I lived in Dairyland.  This is the main treat, a rich malty brew with a smoky edge.  It fades to sweerness as you go , and that to me, is a bit of a drawback, but its a hell of a beer.
Good dark beer, it does not comprimise anything

UPDATED: APR 20, 2005 Absolutely beautiful...what else to expect from a top-notch Milwaukee microbrewer?  Aroma is a spicy chocolate scent.  The flavor is a sharp, tangy carmel that dissolves into a thick malty finish.  Well done indeed.
Smells good, looks good, tastes good.  Thats all there is to say.
I havent had many darks, but this is one of the best that I have had.
Intense, complex maltiness.  Loads of flavour.  One of the worlds best schwarzbiers.
